DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: A wild day in Wall Street. It was one of the most chaotic trading days ever in the markets.

This is Risk and Reward. I'm Deirdre Bolton.

The Dow plunged more than 550 points at session lows. There was an attempt at a rebound and the Dow did close lower but certainly off that very low mark.

Oil dropped a big part of the negative sentiment. Prices fell below $27 per barrel, a level not seen since May of 2003.

We have you covered from all angles. We are going to start right now from the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. My colleague, Lori Rothman there all day. Lori, this one is crazy?

LORI ROTHMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes. You think a bit of a roller coaster ride. I think people it couldn't end soon enough for the folks who are working down here. Although I will say that the higher volume and the increase in volatility is great for traders who make a living of all of that action.

But, yes. I mean, you hit the nail on the head. We were down at the low on the Dow of 566, we came back paring that decline to -- a decline of 250. So, that's about 1.5 percent decline.

I think what happened here mid-session, traders, investors were starting to look at our levels, testing those late summer losses levels there, and said, you know, how many more consecutive days can oil decline 5 percent, 7 percent, you know. And then they realize maybe this is the low, maybe we're at it.

For what is worth the Russell comprised of small mid-cap names, managed to close up about half a percent today. And some key sectors also drove the turn around which are very telling what investors how they view the makeup of the U.S. economy.

So, health care, biotech led the turnaround. In fact, United Health Care led the Dow Jones Industrial average to gain about 2 percent today.

As I mentioned, oil got clobbered. Chevron off 7 percent. Some of the other winners headline names. Nike, American Express, Microsoft, Apple, from a broad range of industries. So, really this was this was, you know, a statement on what U.S. investors think of the U.S. market and what's going to happen here with the U.S. economy.

Fed fund futures are now predicting perhaps only one -- more interest rate hike versus two or three they were looking at late last year, which is one rate hike perhaps this year. We'll see what happens. Back to you.

BOLTON: Lori, thank you so much. I'm going to pick up right on what you just said about oil. As Lori just told that decline a big part of what weighed on the stock market. So, prices in oil, levels not seen in more than 12 and a half years.

Jeff Flock with me now from the CME. So, Jeff, what were traders telling you how low can oil go?

JEFF FLOCK, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Listen, they -- a lot of traders are saying today's move was overplayed because today was the expiration date that the oil price got down lower in the February contract than really it really is. It closed at 26.55, which indeed it looks pretty bad.

But now the true futures prices, the March contract which is now trading and that over $28, even in the afterhours. Now I'm looking at the latest numbers, you know, we're still well over $28. So, maybe things aren't as bad as they look.

And then, Deirdre, if you look even farther out to the out months in terms of the futures I just looked at last hour's, these are last quote, but I think they're Germaine, the May quote is $31, the June quote is almost $32, and in December, we were at $35.

So, the long-range bet oil is that rises even though right now in the short term, you know, it doesn't look good.

BOLTON: We are going to take your words to heart, Jeff Flock. Thank you so much.

FLOCK: I hope.

BOLTON: Joining us there from the CME. So, this markets move was big. It was widespread. It showed up in every asset class. As you were just hearing about.

My power market panel here with their best advice for your money. Market bull, Michael Lee. Market bear, Lee Munson. Straight to our market bull, Michael Lee. You're the contrarian today. Volatility was the theme. Give me one reason to be optimistic on U.S. stocks.

MICHAEL LEE, TIGER WEALTH MANAGEMENT FOUNDER & MANAGING PARTNER: Well, you need this volatility. We need to enter new volatility regime if we're going to break out to new all-time highs as where I think we're going. Based on the economic data we're seeing from the U.S. So, you got a great, great numbers on Friday. In terms of retail sales, up 4.6 percent year-over-year, when you take out gasoline sales.

You look at inflation today, ex food and energy up 2.1 percent. Great jobs number a couple of weeks ago rolling four-week average of job week -- jobless claims. Still at lows that we haven't seen since the 1960s.

So, the U.S. economy is in en fuego, it's just on fire. So, without this new level of volatility there is no way to break out to new all-time highs. So, it is the silver lining in the horror on the screens.

BOLTON: So, Lee, let me pick up with this idea of the U.S. economy going strong. Because Royal Dutch Shell is saying it may have to lay off something like 10,000 workers. And part of this is linked to what we've been talking about with oil's decline. How much before other corporations make that kind of decision?

LEE MUNSON, PORTFOLIO WEALTH ADVISORS PRESIDENT: They're already making it. Because we've got lagging indicators that what Michael is talking about. You know, we're looking today at jobs and consumer sentiment being good in the past. We're going to start seeing tech companies start laying off that oil is going to have a knock-on effect.

This is the same thing we talked in 2008, about why we should save or not save General Motors or Ford because you lay off one person who is making big money, it has a cascading effect.

So, the one thing I want to remind people is that, we don't have volatility yet. I understand that Michael wants to see it. I want volatility to be like me, 40 and over. Look at September of 2011. That's called volatility. We don't even have volatility at same level as the August mini crash.

And quite frankly, I wrote about this last week in Forbes. We busted through the Columbus Day massacre of 2014. So, we have air underneath there. There is no technicality. I want pessimism. I want everybody including Michael to say we've been in the recession, we're in a bear market, then I'm going to go have a beer with Michael and I want to go be bullish for the rest of the year, but not yet.

BOLTON: OK. But to your point, we have in your view fallen beneath some key levels that you think are important?

MUNSON: Yes.

BOLTON: OK.

MUNSON: We do. And that's unfortunately there's not a next little level close by. We could be in the 1700s on the S&P.

BOLTON: All right. Michael, defend yourself because I know you have a different point of view or are you just saying, listen, this is a good opportunity for people who want to own stocks, let's say for the next five years, to pick up companies they like?

LEE: Look, I'm not a day-trader. But to take a step back, the employment numbers are not lagging when they're getting stronger month in and month out. What I think you have here is sovereign wealth fund, who, majority of their money comes from oil are just flushing out the market.

And when the market sells off like this, all the fast money that pushes the market around, i.e. the hedge funds, their money lines get cut by their risk managers. So, it's very, very difficult to get out there and get loud and get long.

Bank of America said last week it was the largest buying they've seen in five years from hedge funds buying U.S. equities. So, I mean, this oil as a bad thing for the U.S. is laughable. You know, maybe we should be thinking...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: Even when we see job cuts coming, Michael?

LEE: You know, U.S. consumes 162 billion of gasoline a year. So, $2 off a gallon of gasoline. that's 362 billion. That's millions of jobs and hundreds of thousands of dollars a year. It is a net positive for the economy. We are service-based import economy consumer driven. So, the less we have spent on gas, the more we can spend on other stuff.

The more the rest of the world goes into hell in a hand basket the better it is for the U.S. consumer. I mean, look, it would be nice if the rest the world were stabilized and not getting worse.

BOLTON: Lee.

LEE: But, you know, these are positive things for us and it's just going to continue to get better.

BOLTON: Lee, what is your point, because Michael's point is well-taken of course. But the ideas we are all now interconnected, right? We heard from China yesterday, slowest growth - China is the world's second largest economy - slowest growth in GDP figures for that country in 25 years. So, to what extent are we affected by other countries?

MUNSON: We are because it's going to affect the price of our dollar which has been one of the saving graces of profits. And also, this idea that oil is laughable that it doesn't matter, you start telling some of my clients here that are having to lay off people who buy other goods and services because they're simply no business in the gas and oil patch.

This is a major part of the U.S. economy. And while I get the idea that it's cheaper gas, not if you're not making any money. I think China is a real issue, but I think that China is actually leading right now. And I think if you want to buy value, look at China, look at Europe. They are already in a bear market. They've had a 20 percent correction. That's where value is right now.

I think in the U.S. you've got to wait. And I think if you want to buy for the next five years, why not just wait for another couple of weeks to see if we can go even lower. You've got nothing to lose if you're long-term investor, right?

BOLTON: OK. So, I hear what you're saying, you're saying don't buy but don't sell. Just wait to see what else develops. I'm going to take a page, though, from Michael's book. Because I did some research, 2008, 2009, in that 24-month period, if you were say, owning stocks, S&P 500 as the index, you lost 24 percent.

But then, by 2012, you had made up your money. So, does this just mean for people who do have patience, that is to say not people who are trying to retire next year, there are opportunities and they should be buying?

LEE: Oh, I'm sorry, me?

BOLTON: Go ahead, Lee.

MUNSON: You know, I think so. I think that we're about 60, we're about 3 or 4 percent from a full bear market in the S&P 500. My point is very simple. Because we broke those key levels, and because we have such a shocking crazy thing about oil, I don't see why we need to necessarily rush in.

I think that what I've told my cleaners is that my bear suit is getting old, and then in the next couple weeks or next couple of months, I'm going to turn it in and I want the bull suit out of the closet. But, I don't think because we went below those levels from August that people should see today as the big green light.

I want to see the VIX at 40, and then I will be like I said with...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: You want everyone to give up and you want to take Michael Lee, our market bull for a bear. That's very generous of you, Lee Munson. Thank you very much. Lee Munson, our market bear. Michael Lee, our market bull.

Well, volatility so far the theme of the year. If you're close to retirement as we were just talking about, our next experts will give you their best advice.

Also, we're going to be talking about how you can avoid working more years than you plan to.

The East Coast may get hit by an epic blizzard. The storm may affect more than 50 million people. But don't panic. Don't clear the grocery store shelves just yet. We're going to bring you the latest information on where the storm precisely is most likely to hit.

And the Senate voting today on such a key issue that two high-profile Senate republicans took time from the presidential campaign trail to cast their votes. Senator John Thune agrees with both, that is to say, Senators Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio on blocking 10,000 Syrian refugees from coming to the U.S.

BOLTON: The East Coast likely to get hit by a mega snowstorm. More than 50 million people may be affected. Rick Reichmuth with me now from the weather center. So, Rick, certain parts of the U.S. could get something like two feet of snow?

RICK REICHMUTH, FOX NEWS METEOROLOGIST: Yes. I think we'll certainly see some two feet snowfall totals from the storm. Probably areas of Virginia and West Virginia. I will show you that. One storm right now is moving through, this is not it, but we'll see a few flurries here. If you see those don't think that's the big storm.

The storm that we're watching is now back across parts of Idaho and Wyoming. And it's a big disturbance right here that over the next day and a half is going to dive down across parts of South and cause big problems for a lot of people.

We have all kinds of winter storm advisories in effect where you see this blue including southern parts of New Jersey. Really the big concern here is where you have this green and that is blizzard watches in effect. We will likely be seeing blizzard conditions Friday night into Saturday for Washington, D.C. and Baltimore. And possibly that will extend a little bit more around that area.

I think that's going to be the bulls eye for the storm. This is the future radar. So, tomorrow, this system is going to bring us a lot of rain including severe weather. We could see some tornadoes down across parts of the south tomorrow. You see behind that cold air that gets in, maybe a little bit of snow here across parts of Mississippi and Arkansas.

I want also to point out areas of Kentucky, maybe into the Carolinas could be looking at some pretty significant icing. That can be devastating. It could looking at some power outages from that. But then Friday, day, we get into the snow, again, parts of West Virginia and Virginia and watch this here, it's all snow for D.C. and Philadelphia right on the border in New York City from this.

Maybe we're going to see some accumulating snowfall, plowable snow indeed in New York. But the bulls eye is going to be here around the D.C. area. And some of those spots may be over two feet of snow. Deirdre.

BOLTON: Rick, thank you as always.

REICHMUTH: You bet.

BOLTON: Rick Reichmuth joining me there on this epic snowstorm.

Well, it was a rocky session in the stock market. The Dow closed down around 1.5 percent after being much lower. So, by some metrics, we're off to the worst start for the U.S. stock market ever.

If you're close to retiring you may be panicking, but don't. Author of "Real Money Answers for Every Woman," Patrice Washington is here. Also financial advisor, David Waddell. Thank you, both, for being here.

Patrice, to the person who is counting on retiring in five years' time, what should he or she be doing now?

PATICE WASHINGTON, "REAL MONEY ANSWER FOR ALL WOMEN" AUTHOR: Well, I say the first thing that you do is still determine what you can handle. This is not time to go baseball on what everyone else is doing. And so, you have to look at your comfort level. I'm sure you guys have heard before, you know that investing is not based on the brain, it's based on the stomach and what you can actually handle.

So, even though this is typically the time you want to be more aggressive, maybe you should back up a little bit and be conservative but just that realistic expectations.

BOLTON: So, David, we take your point there. Should anyone over 50 be putting more money in cash? Meaning, if this market is setting up to be like the one we saw in 2008 and 2009, is it better to look for safe havens, at least with part of your money?

DAVID WADDELL, WADDELL & ASSOCIATES CEO: I think it's too hard to know. And I think anybody who is 50 may have a life expectancy of another 30 years, 40 years. There has never been a 20-year period where the stock market actually produced negative returns.

If you go back 20 years, it's been compounding a 10 percent a year, which by the way, is its long term historic rate of return.

So, I think the first thing investors need to do is refer to their financial plan. And if the financial plan calls for rate of return above 5 percent, then you need some stocks in your portfolio. And you know, over time stocks produce 10 bond, it produce five. You know, figure out what you're required rate of return is and split up the portfolio, and you just kind of got to hold on. It's easy to predict where the bond is...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: David, it sounds easy, but how do you choose? What is your advice when you say you need stocks? Do you say, OK, do the research, the Peter Lynch model, buy what you know? That is to say if you happen to like Apple products, you use it. If you watch Netflix, you buy Netflix, is that the advice that you give to your clients?

WADDELL: No. But then again we're professional financial planners and advisors. And so, the first thing you ought to do is hire good people like the people at Waddell and Associates, right? So, get a good trusted advisor who can also act as psychologist for you and help hold your hand through tumultuous period.

Because the reality is, the market goes down 33 percent of the time, that's just part of the game.

BOLTON: All right. Which gets back to what Patrice said about investing, keeping in mind, your own tolerance for risk. So, Patrice, on that note, when people reach out to you, do you suggest that they buy what they know, or do you suggest something else?

WASHINGTON: Well, I suggest that they also go to a professional. You know, that's the first thing. But I do also suggest that they think about diversifying and not keeping all their eggs in one basket. And that goes beyond the classes. That goes beyond the stocks and bonds and short term investments.

It goes even deeper in each of those classes, what are the different companies that appeal to you.

BOLTON: All right. We will leave it there. Short, sweet, to the point. Patrice Washington, David Waddell. Thank you very much.

WADDELL: Thank you.

WASHINGTON: Thank you.

BOLTON: Congress investigating an increase in number of terror plots hatched by foreign-born residents. Also, the Department of Homeland Security warning that more than half a million foreigners overstayed their visas. We will see if there is a connection in some cases.

Also, a huge vote in the Senate today, so important that two GOP presidential candidates left the campaign trail to be in D.C. At issue, blocking 10,000 Syrian refugees from coming to the U.S.

My guest is Senator John Thune says we need to hold off on allowing refugees in. He says democrats are making a grave mistake in arguing the counter point. Senator Thune is my guest next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAMES COMEY, FBI DIRECTOR: In all 50 states we have opened terrorism investigations related to number of dimensions of the threat. In all 50 states we have ISIL radicalization cases under investigation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Senate democrats want to let Syrian and Iraqi refugees into the U.S. Republicans say it would be huge mistake.

Republican Senator from South Dakota, John Thune is with me now. Senator, glad to have you here.

JOHN THUNE, SOUTH DAKOTA SENATOR: Nice to be here. Thanks, Deirdre.

BOLTON: Senators Rubio and Cruz went to D.C. today, in other words, even got off the campaign trail which is hot to try to address this issue. What happened?

THUNE: Well, what happened, Deirdre, was a bill came over from the House, that calls for vetting certification by the Department of Homeland Security, the FBI, and the Director of National Intelligence, that refugees coming into this country do not present a security risk to people in this country.

So, it's a simple, fairly simple bill. I think a fairly reasonable bill. We tried to call it up today to just be able to debate it and amend it and the democrats blocked it from even being considered. It's called the motion to proceed. It takes 60 votes to get on a bill. And the democrats had the requisite number to stop it. So, that's what happened on the floor today.

It's a big issue. It's an issue. It's important to our national security and one that I think needs to be addressed and the fact that the democrats were willing, on this procedural vote today to block it, I think is going to be very difficult for them to defend.

BOLTON: So, Senator, I want to ask you, because you introduced an amendment to the bill that would give governors the ability to refuse taking refugees. Did the Senate and any of the democrats or anyone you're speaking with recognize that each state, that is to say, the governor, understands resources and the difference in resources in his or her state?

THUNE: Right. Unfortunately, Deirdre, because the democrats blocked this, prevented us from even getting on the bill, I didn't get an opportunity to debate or have that amendment voted on. But I filed it. And it's very -- yes, it's very simple.

We heard from 30 governors last year who want to be able to have some control over their borders and who comes in. And so, all of this simply would have done is allow them to have more participation in that process to meet with the Secretary of State's Office when they're having these discussions about vetting refugees.

And hopefully, to have more input into it. And then if they, you know, if they decide that there are concerns that their state has about admitting certain people, that they would be able not to have to do that. So, that's what the amendment did.

But unfortunately we didn't get a chance to amend -- or to debate that simply because they blocked the consideration of the bill.

BOLTON: The Governor of Kansas was with us a few weeks ago. And he said he is very concerned for his resident's safety, which is the point that you made right when we began speaking.

I want to ask you also about something, Senator, that you wrote, an op-ed style of piece on President Obama and the numerous executive orders that he is trying to pass in his last year in office. We just want to bring our viewers up to speed with some comments that the president made back in 2014.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA PRESIDENT: I've got a pen and I've got a phone. I've got a pen to take executive actions where Congress won't and I've got a telephone. I've got a pen and I've got a phone.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So, this message that in his last year of office was the implication, obviously when he was speaking in 2014, that he was just going to try to push through unilaterally as much as possible. To what extent is this tarnishing his legacy?

THUNE: Well, and I think even this week, his spokesperson said that he is going to be audacious in using executive action to accomplish his objectives. And the problem with that, I tried to point this out in the op- ed, Deirdre, is if you live by executive action you're going to die by executive action.

And if he's really interested in having a legacy he gave that up when he determined that he was going to go around to the Congress basically, ignore the people's representatives and try and accomplish his agenda through regulatory action, executive orders and that sort of thing.

And what that means is, that can be overturned by the next president. And many of his executive actions have ended up in the courts. And the courts have ruled against him. So his, much of his agenda, the things that he wanted to accomplish have been done by executive order which is a very fleeting accomplishment.

It doesn't endure and it's not going to stand the test of time. And I think that this president is going to go down in history as somebody who tried to assert more power if the Executive Branch, probably than anybody since Woodrow Wilson. And that's not a good formula for how to get things done for the American people.

BOLTON: And even as you rightly point out, Senator, from a practical standpoint, if the Supreme Court is going to be forced to check some of these measures, it's a use of everyone's time. Senator John Thune, thank you as always, joining us there...

THUNE: Thanks, Deirdre.

BOLTON: ... from Capitol Hill.

More market mayhem when we come back. Some details that may be useful to you as you try to manage your portfolio. Apple, you can see on the charts there. We're going to talk about this price point of $100 per stock if Apple goes back over that, if it's a good buy. We'll discuss it.

Also, President Obama said, one big regret was not getting along with Congress.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

OBAMA: It is one of the few regrets of my presidency, that the rancor and suspicion between the parties has gotten worse instead of better.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: My next guest, two Senate leaders who never got along but now it's different. Former Senator Trent Lott, former Senator Tom Daschle. They are going to be joining me in just two minutes.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: It was a wild market day. The Dow down by more than 550 points at its session low. Fox Business' Gerri Willis with me now. Gerri, you were watching right along with me. Winners and losers, I know you were picking them out, what did you find?

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS REPORTER: Let me tell you, what a day. A total rollercoaster. When I first started watching the markets all Dow stocks were down. But now by the end of session we've actually got some winners here. United Health got 1.96 percent. That was a winner on the day. Nike, up 1.23 percent. MX, marginally higher, Microsoft, marginally higher, Apple, marginally higher, up 13/100, believe it or not.

But you got to say positive is good here. On the other side, the flip side, the losers, IBM. Now remember that IBM had a bad report showing that its revenues now for 15 consecutive quarters have turned it down. IBM, down 4.88 percent. That accounts for 41 Dow points. Think about that.

Exxon, down. Oil obviously a big loser here down 4.21 percent. Cisco down 3.98 percent. A big tech company, you've got to think that they're selling into overseas markets; maybe it's the worry over those. Boeing as well, 3.1 percent. Chevron, another oil stock down 3.1 percent.

It's hard to imagine but oil is down 74 percent from its highs. These stocks continuing to languish. And when you look at the sectors on the day, healthcare had the best performance, energy had the worst predictably. Deirdre, back to you.

BOLTON: Predictably, indeed with as you rightly point out, Gerri. Oil trading at more than a 12-year low. Gerri Willis, thank you so much.

WILLIS: You're welcome.

BOLTON: Volatility in the markets, volatility in D.C. as well. Both sides of the aisle blaming each other for a lack of progress and financial waste.

Republicans, for example, blaming the divide on D.C. on President Obama and his overreached in executive action.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA PRESIDENT: It's one of the few regrets of my presidency that the rancor and suspicion between the parties has gotten worse instead of better.

I told my administration to keep looking every single for actions we can take without Congress.

With Congress, we're on my own.

Now I'm going to be working with Congress where I can to accomplish this. But I'm also going to act on my own if Congress is deadlocked.

Where Congress isn't acting I'll act on my own.

Whenever and wherever, I can take steps without legislation to expand opportunities for more American families, that's what I'm going to do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: My next two guests know a thing or two about duking it out on the Hill in years' past.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TOM DASCHLE, FORMER SOUTH DAKOTA SENATOR: And we are getting a resounding no on the other side of the aisle. We are getting an absolute emphatic no with an exclamation point. We got to find a way with which to address this bill in a more consequential and productive way.

TRENT LOTT, FORMER MISSISSIPPI SENATOR: This thing has done as I said in other forums. This has become a problem of greed. Do you want to do something about this problem or do you want to play games. It's not clear to me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Former Senate majority leader, here they are, democrat Tom Daschle and republican Trent Lott, they say that partisan gridlock has become a national crisis and have authored a new book called "Crisis Point." Which I must say is a great read. I am so pleased to have you both here.

LOTT: Thank you for having us, Deirdre.

DASCHLE: Thank you.

BOLTON: So, thank you for coming in. What can we learn -- I'm going to start with you, Senator Daschle, about the future based on what you have seen in the past?

DASCHLE: Well, I think what we need to know about the future is just what kind of cooperation, what kind of communication, what kinds of relationship will our political leaders have. How much will the president invite congressional leaders to work together? How much will congressional reciprocate. That will tell a lot about the quality of governance we're going to see in the next three years.

BOLTON: Senator Lott, how is it different, how is the environment in Washington, D.C. different? It feels worse now than ever but I want to know from someone who's actually been there.

LOTT: Well, first, in the book we talk about there were difficult times in history going back to the period of our founding father. I mean, Berg did kill Hamilton and Jefferson hated Adams, and so forth. And of course we have this war here.

It is the worse I've seen in the 50 years that I've been watching it pretty closely, as a political science major and as a lawyer and being in Washington and Congress. A whole lot of things have caused this. But these are difficult and different times. They are different people.

Media is very different, not only, you know, TV, cable...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: Oh, I know it, right? And social...

LOTT: ... but also social media has made a huge impact. But also, I really felt a changing in 2004, slipping and sliding, it was getting meaner spirited. It was also getting more and more difficult to get positive things done in Washington.

Now, look, there is plenty of blame to go around. Congress, the president, the republicans, the democrats. But those clips that you showed of the president, it agitated me just sitting here. Because, you know, you've got to reach out to the Congress. And you can't just do it on your own.

BOLTON: Where you had to lead, right?

LOTT: And, you know, that's one of the number one. We've talked about that, communication, chemistry, leadership and vision. What did the candidates this year want to do for our country? Tell me something positive.

BOLTON: Speaking of the candidates, when you talk about these qualities that I assume you agree with your fine colleague here...

(CROSSTALK)

DASCHLE: I do, strongly.

BOLTON: ... are necessary, what do you see when, for example, there are business people who want to be leaders, which is not necessarily a bad thing. But what can they bring as far as all those qualities that are necessary to lead?

DASCHLE: Well, I hope we'll have our leaders who, not only are successful business people or business leaders, but people who understand the importance of the institutions. These institutions were created for a reason. They were giving people an opportunity through their elected leadership to self-govern through our democratic republic.

These institutions have stood the test of time. What we have to do is respect them. We have to make sure that we continue to let them be that critical element to our democratic republic. If we fail to do that we're going to lose a vital element to democracy as we look forward.

LOTT: You know, there are awful lot of lawyers in the Congress not enough business men and women and people who out there professions. And I like the fact that business people realize they need to be involved, too. I would like to have more realtors to be involved, for instance.

My son is been a small businessman and he likes the fact that we got a businessman running for president. However, being President of United States is not something you do learning on the job. You need to have experience. You need to have been in the Congress. So, work in the administration you understand the leaders...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: It's a compromise is a big part of it but when you are the boss, you just get to be the boss, right?

LOTT: Yes. But, you know, compromise is now considered a dirty word. I don't think it is. In my opinion, it is the art of governing. I mean, Tom and I are friends and I trust Tom and I respect. We didn't agree for a couple of...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: But when -- I was going to say, when you're both on Capitol Hill, you probably didn't feel that generous.

LOTT: No, we did actually.

DASCHLE: No, we did actually pass...

BOLTON: OK.

DASCHLE: ... one of the lessons learned is that, if you build a relationship you can overcome the differences. He's a republican, I'm a democrat. He's center right and I'm to the left. But we found ways with which to bring together the consensus necessary to move this country forward in public policy that brought us a balanced budget, that brought us an array of public policy production that we don't see at the quality and at the volume we need today.

LOTT: You know, a lot of what we did was not partisan in either way. Safe drinking water, are we for that? That shouldn't be republican or democrat. Affordability of insurance. Telecommunications reform. Adequate military pay for our men and women in uniform. None of those are partisan or shouldn't be when we did those things.

BOLTON: Well, I hope that all the candidates read your books. Thank you so much for coming in.

DASCHLE: Thanks for having us.

BOLTON: Senators Tom Daschle and Trent Lott, glad to have you here.

When we come back, politicians are pushing Silicon Valley and tech companies to help fight terrorism. We have an attorney who is suing Twitter, blaming the social media company for the rise of ISIS.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAMES COMEY, FBI DIRECTOR: ISIL has used that ubiquitous social media to break the model and push into the United States into the pocket on to the mobile device of troubled souls throughout our country in all 50 states, a twin message. Come or kill. Come or kill.

Come to the so-called caliphate, live a life of glory, participate in the final battle between good and evil on God's side. Come to the caliphate. If you can't come, kill where you are.

Social media works to connect us. It works us a way to sell cars or shoes or a movie. It works to crowd source terrorism. And so, starting in the summer of 2014, they really invested in this and it works. It led to troubled souls convincing themselves that there was meaning for them in Syria and Iraq, or that they have should engage in acts of violence in the United States.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARCO RUBIO, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: This is not an issue of process, it's an issue of information. And there is just not enough information about people coming from Syria. What's inexplicable is that there was information available and that we didn't look at it because of some policy designed to be politically correct and not offend people. That's unacceptable in the time of war.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: That was GOP presidential candidate, Senator Marco Rubio criticizing officials for failing to check social media accounts of the San Bernardino shooters.

The widow of a defense contractor killed by ISIS is suing Twitter for helping the terrorist's group to grow. Tamara Fields' husband, Carl Fields Jr. was killed in November in Jordan by a lone gunman. Now, ISIS took credit for that atrocity and then promoted it on social media.

Josh Arisohn is with me now. He is representing Ms. Fields. So, we are glad to have you here, Josh. Thanks for coming in.

JOSH ARISOHN, MS. FIELDS' LAWYER: Thanks for having me.

BOLTON: What do you think the chances of your case are? Because I'm assuming that all social media platforms come back with the same argument that is to say, we are the pipes, we do not monitor the contents.

ARISOHN: Well, we feel strong about both the law and the facts in this case and about the case going forward. And, you know, Twitter wasn't just the pipes here. Twitter for a long time has known that ISIS is on social network. And it's been criticized by the White House and members of Congress and the FBI, and it has done little to act.

And so, if you go on t Twitter today, it's still very easy to find ISIS accounts and tweets and hash tags supporting ISIS.

BOLTON: So, Josh, you're building your case now as we speak. Are there any lessons to be taken, for example, from fighting child pornography? Because I know that is another issue that a lot of the social media companies have had to deal with where they actually have had to draw a line and say, to your point, OK, we are more than just a plumbing system. We are more than just a dissemination system.

ARISOHN: Well, the fight against child pornography online is actually a really good model that I think Twitter should follow in the area of terrorism. Using technology they've largely been able to get rid of child pornography on web sites like Twitter.

And according to the experts that we've spoken to, the same technology or similar technology could be used to eradicate ISIS, once and for all from Twitter. But for whatever reason, Twitter has declined to use that technology.

BOLTON: So, Josh, how concerned are you at this juncture Twitter stock is in the gutter. The company has really gone through numerous management changes. It seems like it's struggling at this particular moment. Even if you succeed, do you worry about the company's future to even paying Ms. Fields?

ARISOHN: I'm not really worried about Twitter's finances. We're focused on getting and making Twitter accountable for providing material support to a terrorist organization and trying to get them to influence some changes to get ISIS to get ISIS off of its social network once and for all.

BOLTON: Well, if you win this would be a big landmark case. We wish you luck.

ARISOHN: Thank you.

BOLTON: Thank you, Josh. Josh Arisohn joining me there. He is representing the widow of a contractor who was killed in Jordan.

If you own gold you were spared some of today's market volatility or at least feeling it in your gut. The precious metal jumping more than 4 percent since the start of the year.

We are going to speak with my next guest who says gold prices could go even higher. We will also bring you the very latest on Flint, Michigan water crisis. Protesters are calling for the governors to resign. But my next guest says that the real culprit is government spending.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We've been fighting too long. We need more help. We need Obama to come in here and change these pipes. It's not about anything else. We need the pipes changed in this city. You know, they are talking about giving us filters and going around giving us water? How long is that going to last?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Stock market volatility showed up in the form of stocks and oil falling and gold rising. Industries often want to hold gold in times of fear or uncertainty.

RJO Futures, Phil Streible with me now from the CME. So, Phil, given the volatility, how high can gold go?

PHIL STREIBLE, RJO FUTURES SENIOR MARKET STRATEGIST: That's a good question. I really think gold prices could surge a lot higher. I think we could see the 1150 or even 1200. It really depends on how bad the situation deteriorates.

Now remember, last year, gold prices traveled bound to about, you know, 1050. We are in a rising interest rate environment. We have a stronger dollar and we had created global growth. We are starting to see kind of the opposite effect take place. Not necessarily the dollar index weakening too much but we are seeing other foreign currencies like the Eurozone.

They are embarking on quantitative easing. Global growth, it seems like it's been tossed out the window. There is a lot of concern about China. And remember, the Fed, they were expected to have four interest rates this year, then it got cut down to two. Now it looks like the Fed funds are pricing in a December rate hike.

BOLTON: OK. So, the Fed, oil, China. I want to bring in a few comments here from Harold Hamm. He's a billionaire oil executive. He's actually saying Saudi Arabia is to blame for some of the energy volatility.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HAROLD HAMM, OIL AND GAS EXECUTIVE: Oil in a rebalancing situation has come about, basically at the hands of OPEC or primary Saudi Arabia that decided last Thanksgiving, frankly to put, a year ago in 2014, to put the 1.8 million barrels of new oil on the market. Basically, to try to drown out our success as shale players here in the U.S.

And so, they have been attempting to do that and put us out of business. And, you know, it has an effect. We are down to the lowest rig count since 1999. We've lost quarter million people, direct jobs. About three times that many indirect jobs. So, that's the effect that it's having.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Royal Dutch Shell backing up our gas saying, in fact, it may lay off up to 10,000 people. Do you think is a move by Saudi Arabia to hurt the U.S. energy industry or to hurt the Iranian energy industry?

STREIBLE: Well, I don't think that they are trying to hurt anybody. I think that they are in a race against Iran as far as getting oil into the system.

I remember, you know, we'll probably going to see Iran pump about 500,000 barrels a day. So, the thing is that, they weren't trying to hurt them. They're just trying to get ahead. As far as the U.S., it's all just a, you know, a technological change. We had now the ability to frack oil and produce quite a bit of it.

But Saudi Arabia doesn't want to let up any of that market share. So, of course, it's going to drive businesses out of, you know, business. A credit crisis is probably going to occur. And I think once you see a credit crisis occur in the oil and gas industry, then I think finally a bottom may be in place because our production will have already peaked.

BOLTON: Right.

STREIBLE: You know, it picked last year at 9.6 million. I think we come back down into the 7's before we start to turn back around.

BOLTON: All right, Phil. Great to have you here. Thank you. Phil Streible joining me there from the CME.

Protesters are calling for the governor to step down in Flint, Michigan over the water crisis. My next guest says people should actually be looking at their own frivolous spending. And by that, he means the states and the federal government.

BOLTON: TransPro Consulting CEO, Mark Aesch joining me with how much the government in Flint, Michigan knew about the water crisis, when and to what extent overspending contributed to the crisis there now.

So, Mark, I'm very glad to have you with me. What can the city of Flint, Michigan do now?

MARK AESCH, TRANSPRO CONSULTING CEO: Well, I got to tell you. You couldn't help but notice today the mayor's comments at the White House when she was meeting with, you know, the president and others where she talked about the short-sightedness that the leadership in Michigan has provided from the state.

The reality is, it's the short-sightedness of the city itself where they were spending 60 percent more money than they took in every year that really caused this entire crisis.

They had purchased water from Detroit for years and it was fine. Because they went into receivership, because they were spending too much money, that's really what caused this crisis to be where it is today.

BOLTON: Mark, please come back. I would like to talk more about this. Mark Aesch, joining me these saying overspending is part of the problem in Flint, Michigan. He will join us another day, I hope.

Thank you for joining us here on Risk and Reward. Making Money with Charles Payne starts now.

RIVA GOLD, REPORTER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: The only things that are really still up here are the auto sector in Europe and Italian stocks, as well as tiny bit, is left of Hong Kong's gains.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Riva, thank you so much.

GOLD: Thanks for having me.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN HOST: And that is it for us. Over to Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo this morning. Hey Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Good morning ladies. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It is Wednesday, February 7th. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Volatility slamming Wall Street investors from Coast-to-Coast. They were in for a wild ride yesterday as the DOW finish the day up nearly 600 points after falling by about the same amount in earlier trading. All of the -- as of yesterday's close, all three of those major market gauges are back in positive territory for the year.

But Futures are telling a different story, 243 point loss on the DOW Futures this morning. Again, will volatility end this bull market coming on its nine-year anniversary next month, we will ask that question. Meantime, the economy still looks strong, the Atlanta Federal Reserve did lower its first-quarter GDP forecast to four percent, still hot but that's down from 5.4 percent last week.

In Europe, stocks are heading higher. We have some modest gains across the board in England, France, and Germany but in Asia overnight, stocks mostly lower. The Kospi in South Korea, the worst performer there. The Nikkei managing to eke out a small gain but the Kospi up by more than two percent.

The budget battles looming, lawmakers have until tomorrow night to reach an agreement to keep the federal government running as the House passes a stopgap spending bill, the fight now turns to the Senate where immigration remains a top issue. President Trump weighing in from the White House yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If we don't change it, let's have a shutdown, we'll do a shutdown and it's worth it for our country. I'd love to see a shutdown if we don't get this stuff taken care of.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The latest on the immigration battle ahead. Steve Wynn, out. The details as the billionaire mogul steps down as CEO of his company following sexual misconduct claims.

SpaceX takes it to infinity and beyond.

(VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The company launching their most powerful rocket since the Apollo mission. Sending a Tesla Roadster into orbit as well, more on the giant leap for the private space race ahead.

Plus, winter is coming to a galaxy far, far away. From ESPN to "Star Wars", the Disney earnings, a fan's dream. The new details on the company's fourth streaming service and its plans that came with the mind behind "Game of Thrones."

All that and so much more coming up this morning, FOX News Correspondent, Lea Gabrielle is here. FOX News Contributor, 32Advisors Founder and CEO and Former Economic Advisor to President Obama, Robert Wolf. And CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell. Good morning to everybody.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning.

ROBERT WOLF, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Great too.

MCDOWELL: This is when I'm very happy. We have some age on the panel, myself included because we remember what this kind of all feels it looks like.

WOLF: You know, I'm thinking that -- I think I was in middle school when we had this volatility.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Really?

WOLF: It's been like a -- let's be honest, outside of the dot-com bubble and the Asia crisis and the 2008 recession, we've kind of been on a three- decade, one directional ride. We haven't seen the 1,200 point swing, I can't remember.

MCDOWELL: We want to make it there, yes.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: I mean, it turns out the stock market actually goes down sometimes, right? It should be a really -- this should be a wakeup call for investors, retail investors especially. What do you have in your portfolio? You need to know.

MCDOWELL: Well I think that people already got a wakeup call Lindsey and we will talk about that with people betting on stable markets with these inverse volatility funds, a couple of them shutting down yesterday. We're talking about massive losses, so it's not just individuals, that some of the smartest minds, some of the smartest guys and gals in the room, again, also losing money.

GABRIELLE: And a lot of computers involved in what was going on, of course, to those algorithms have certainly changed how the work is being done.

WOLF: No question.

MCDOWELL: We're going to talk about it all this morning. Coming up, White House Director of Legislative Affairs, Marc Short is here. New York Congressman Tom Suozzi, New York Congresswoman, Claudia Tenney, that's on the left and the right, we'll have them on together. Louisiana Senator, John Kennedy, and former George W. Bush Chief of Staff Business Roundtable President and CEO, Josh Bolton.

You don't want to miss any of those guests but first for our top story, Wall Street bouncing back, U.S. markets rallying to regain almost half their losses from the day before when stocks took the largest plunge in six and a half years, that is the percentage loss that we saw on the DOW. The DOW ending the day with a gain of 567 points. After closing, down more than 1,100 points on Monday. Futures right now are showing losses across the board, 243 point loss on the DOW Futures.

Despite the turbulence, Treasury Secretary Steve MNuchin telling lawmakers on Capitol Hill that the markets are functioning, "Very well."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, U.S. TREASURY SECRETARY: We are very focused on the long- term economic growth and we believe that the policies that we've enacted including tax reform are very positive for a long-term economic growth. We're already beginning to see that in terms of corporate investments back into the United States and the impact on corporate earnings.

I think as you said that the stock market is up significantly over 30 percent since President Trump was elected, we're monitoring the stock markets, they're functioning very well, and we continue to believe in the long-term impact of the stock market.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Lindsey, your take on what Secretary MNuchin is saying but also in volatility going to threaten this nine-year bull market?

BELL: I think volatility certainly has a shot at ruining it but look, last year, there were eight days that we saw a move of one percent plus or minus on the S&P500. Historically, we usually see about 50 of those days. And when you have a year like that, the next year, you're bound to have more volatility. So, I think people should buckle in and get ready for more of that.

MCDOWELL: What all this referencing is, again, it was this sense of calm leads to overconfidence. Among individual investors and professional investors that people kind of become delusional about their ability and you had all these bets on stable markets, this inverse volatility.

These were exchange-traded retail products, two of which including the XIV closed down to investors after they lost most of their money of late Monday. So, again, these losses, the tide goes out and you see who was swimming naked.

WOLF: Well, I won't comment on the swimming naked but what I will say is we realize financial engineering doesn't always work and program trading sometimes the pendulum goes too far each lane, you have these types of swings.

My concerns are two-fold, one, I think the administration is talking way too much about the stock market. I think President Trump, I think he should take a lot of credit for the rally but to talk about it literally every day, it's not the gauge on the economy we should be using as 50 percent of the nation doesn't even own stocks.

MCDOWELL: Well I've been saying that literally since he took office.

WOLF: Well that's where I took it from. And I think secondly, I think that I know as the oldest one on this desk, I have not been in a market that we've seen this type of back up and rates starting, inflation feeling protectionist environment, problems with the fiscal deficit on one side, and then the other side, decent growth, you have the tax cuts that are going to be almost like its own quantitative easing and then lastly, good corporate profits. There's a real tug of war that's going to go in 2018.

MCDOWELL: Well who's going to win because I will push back because I've been concerned about interest rate moving up since really the end of last year but with inflation now come -- with wages now growing at close to three percent which happened in the most recent month.

That's -- still, wages are still -- growth is still very muted, inflation is still muted. And all the signs in the market, for the most part, do say that the economy is OK if not, great.

WOLF: So I would say -- first of all, I would say the bulls will win short-term because the tax reform is going to be the sugar candy for corporate growth. And I think you're going to see that short-term soft buybacks, dividend, some M&A activity.

MCDOWELL: So, we've -- go ahead, finish your --

KEENEY: And, you know, so we're happy that they're spending money. I think we'd be happy if they raised another $20 billion to get this off the ground.

MCDOWELL: So, you get the Tesla in space but you also have the CEO Elon Musk, the founder of the company who's busy with all these other pursuits including SpaceX. Concerned.

KEENEY: That's a valid point. You know, I think Elon Musk is a really amazing person. We saw in this rocket launch, he is capable of making the impossible possible, and so, you know, while no one has achieved this feat yet, I wouldn't put it past him.

MCDOWELL: OK. Tasha, Tasha Keeney, thank you so much.

KEENEY: Thanks for having me. Final thoughts when we come back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Final thoughts. Lindsey?

BELL: Get ready for this political uncertainty to drive that volatility.

MCDOWELL: Robert?

WOLF: Congrats to the Eagles, great year for the Pats, and I've already moved to the Celtics.

MCDOWELL: Yes, I would, too. Lea?

GABRIELLE: Ask for a military parade, that you can see our ships on parade, our submarines on parade, our soldiers, our sailors, airmen, and marines around the world. From Stephen LeClair who's a former marine, he says he wants to spend time with his family on July 4th, not in a parade.

MCDOWELL: And I say to the Democrats, stop talking down the economy and essentially rooting for a downfall for the markets, bad for them. Stuart, over to you.

VARNEY: Oh, I'll take it, Dagen. Thank you very much, indeed. It is not over but is it calming down a bit? OK. I'm on dangerous ground.

END

RIVA GOLD, REPORTER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: The only things that are really still up here are the auto sector in Europe and Italian stocks, as well as tiny bit, is left of Hong Kong's gains.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Riva, thank you so much.

GOLD: Thanks for having me.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN HOST: And that is it for us. Over to Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo this morning. Hey Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Good morning ladies. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It is Wednesday, February 7th. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Volatility slamming Wall Street investors from Coast-to-Coast. They were in for a wild ride yesterday as the DOW finish the day up nearly 600 points after falling by about the same amount in earlier trading. All of the -- as of yesterday's close, all three of those major market gauges are back in positive territory for the year.

But Futures are telling a different story, 243 point loss on the DOW Futures this morning. Again, will volatility end this bull market coming on its nine-year anniversary next month, we will ask that question. Meantime, the economy still looks strong, the Atlanta Federal Reserve did lower its first-quarter GDP forecast to four percent, still hot but that's down from 5.4 percent last week.

In Europe, stocks are heading higher. We have some modest gains across the board in England, France, and Germany but in Asia overnight, stocks mostly lower. The Kospi in South Korea, the worst performer there. The Nikkei managing to eke out a small gain but the Kospi up by more than two percent.

The budget battles looming, lawmakers have until tomorrow night to reach an agreement to keep the federal government running as the House passes a stopgap spending bill, the fight now turns to the Senate where immigration remains a top issue. President Trump weighing in from the White House yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If we don't change it, let's have a shutdown, we'll do a shutdown and it's worth it for our country. I'd love to see a shutdown if we don't get this stuff taken care of.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The latest on the immigration battle ahead. Steve Wynn, out. The details as the billionaire mogul steps down as CEO of his company following sexual misconduct claims.

SpaceX takes it to infinity and beyond.

(VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The company launching their most powerful rocket since the Apollo mission. Sending a Tesla Roadster into orbit as well, more on the giant leap for the private space race ahead.

Plus, winter is coming to a galaxy far, far away. From ESPN to "Star Wars", the Disney earnings, a fan's dream. The new details on the company's fourth streaming service and its plans that came with the mind behind "Game of Thrones."

All that and so much more coming up this morning, FOX News Correspondent, Lea Gabrielle is here. FOX News Contributor, 32Advisors Founder and CEO and Former Economic Advisor to President Obama, Robert Wolf. And CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell. Good morning to everybody.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning.

ROBERT WOLF, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Great too.

MCDOWELL: This is when I'm very happy. We have some age on the panel, myself included because we remember what this kind of all feels it looks like.

WOLF: You know, I'm thinking that -- I think I was in middle school when we had this volatility.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Really?

WOLF: It's been like a -- let's be honest, outside of the dot-com bubble and the Asia crisis and the 2008 recession, we've kind of been on a three- decade, one directional ride. We haven't seen the 1,200 point swing, I can't remember.

MCDOWELL: We want to make it there, yes.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: I mean, it turns out the stock market actually goes down sometimes, right? It should be a really -- this should be a wakeup call for investors, retail investors especially. What do you have in your portfolio? You need to know.

MCDOWELL: Well I think that people already got a wakeup call Lindsey and we will talk about that with people betting on stable markets with these inverse volatility funds, a couple of them shutting down yesterday. We're talking about massive losses, so it's not just individuals, that some of the smartest minds, some of the smartest guys and gals in the room, again, also losing money.

GABRIELLE: And a lot of computers involved in what was going on, of course, to those algorithms have certainly changed how the work is being done.

WOLF: No question.

MCDOWELL: We're going to talk about it all this morning. Coming up, White House Director of Legislative Affairs, Marc Short is here. New York Congressman Tom Suozzi, New York Congresswoman, Claudia Tenney, that's on the left and the right, we'll have them on together. Louisiana Senator, John Kennedy, and former George W. Bush Chief of Staff Business Roundtable President and CEO, Josh Bolton.

You don't want to miss any of those guests but first for our top story, Wall Street bouncing back, U.S. markets rallying to regain almost half their losses from the day before when stocks took the largest plunge in six and a half years, that is the percentage loss that we saw on the DOW. The DOW ending the day with a gain of 567 points. After closing, down more than 1,100 points on Monday. Futures right now are showing losses across the board, 243 point loss on the DOW Futures.

Despite the turbulence, Treasury Secretary Steve MNuchin telling lawmakers on Capitol Hill that the markets are functioning, "Very well."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, U.S. TREASURY SECRETARY: We are very focused on the long- term economic growth and we believe that the policies that we've enacted including tax reform are very positive for a long-term economic growth. We're already beginning to see that in terms of corporate investments back into the United States and the impact on corporate earnings.

I think as you said that the stock market is up significantly over 30 percent since President Trump was elected, we're monitoring the stock markets, they're functioning very well, and we continue to believe in the long-term impact of the stock market.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Lindsey, your take on what Secretary MNuchin is saying but also in volatility going to threaten this nine-year bull market?

BELL: I think volatility certainly has a shot at ruining it but look, last year, there were eight days that we saw a move of one percent plus or minus on the S&P500. Historically, we usually see about 50 of those days. And when you have a year like that, the next year, you're bound to have more volatility. So, I think people should buckle in and get ready for more of that.

MCDOWELL: What all this referencing is, again, it was this sense of calm leads to overconfidence. Among individual investors and professional investors that people kind of become delusional about their ability and you had all these bets on stable markets, this inverse volatility.

These were exchange-traded retail products, two of which including the XIV closed down to investors after they lost most of their money of late Monday. So, again, these losses, the tide goes out and you see who was swimming naked.

WOLF: Well, I won't comment on the swimming naked but what I will say is we realize financial engineering doesn't always work and program trading sometimes the pendulum goes too far each lane, you have these types of swings.

My concerns are two-fold, one, I think the administration is talking way too much about the stock market. I think President Trump, I think he should take a lot of credit for the rally but to talk about it literally every day, it's not the gauge on the economy we should be using as 50 percent of the nation doesn't even own stocks.

MCDOWELL: Well I've been saying that literally since he took office.

WOLF: Well that's where I took it from. And I think secondly, I think that I know as the oldest one on this desk, I have not been in a market that we've seen this type of back up and rates starting, inflation feeling protectionist environment, problems with the fiscal deficit on one side, and then the other side, decent growth, you have the tax cuts that are going to be almost like its own quantitative easing and then lastly, good corporate profits. There's a real tug of war that's going to go in 2018.

MCDOWELL: Well who's going to win because I will push back because I've been concerned about interest rate moving up since really the end of last year but with inflation now come -- with wages now growing at close to three percent which happened in the most recent month.

That's -- still, wages are still -- growth is still very muted, inflation is still muted. And all the signs in the market, for the most part, do say that the economy is OK if not, great.

WOLF: So I would say -- first of all, I would say the bulls will win short-term because the tax reform is going to be the sugar candy for corporate growth. And I think you're going to see that short-term soft buybacks, dividend, some M&A activity.

But I think long-term, people are going to project out a backup of rates and when we start getting three and a half, four percent, you're going to see a shift take place from equity to fixed income, you're just going to see it because risk free returns are going to start to look good versus a market that's been pretty buoyant. I mean, that's just one thing I do have as experience 30 years. I can't say how much in the market today.

MCDOWELL: It sounds like you're calling longer term for a bear market in stocks and bonds because, again, if -- because we've had a bull market in bonds since the early 1980s. Did you --

WOLF: I wouldn't say a bear market but I think the bears will beat the bulls probably come towards late 2018, early 2019 as we see in just to my opinion this nervousness. We're going to do better, growth is here, wages will do better, the labor force is starting to tighten. Those are just facts. And we have a whole new Fed environment with Powell coming in.

BELL: I think it's going to depend largely on inflation and interest rates as well and inflation is going to be driven by that wage number. If we get productivity which it seems like we should get better productivity, the inflation won't come in high-speed manner that is sort of expected kind of market right now.

GABRIELLE: Any concerns about the impact to the economy because of tax reform if the Fed ends up tightening at monetary policy because of inflation as some are talking about right now and also -- MCDOWELL: Well they are tightening monetary policies. They're reducing their balance sheets, it's already down to $4 trillion and they're already raising interesting rates.

GABRIELLE: Right. But the question is, if interest rates if we get four instead of three, if things change as they are trying to cool down the economy getting too heated up, do you have any concerns over the tax cuts and how that might have an impact on the deficit and debt?

WOLF: Well I do. I mean, I've been speaking about it, yes, I'm a pro- growth Democrat but I have been -- I am fiscally pretty hawkish in a sense that I think if everything should have been revenue neutral, I believe in the PAYGO system. And so my view is although I was supportive of tax reform, I probably would have looked to have done -- I would have done it - -

MCDOWELL: So you were up -- so you were concerned that that --

WOLF: I was concerned on the fiscal side sometimes.

MCDOWELL: Well -- so you were also concerned when the national debt doubled under President Obama.

WOLF: Absolutely.

MCDOWELL: Did you fell in that as his economic advisor?

WOLF: We're talking about -- we're looking -- the answer -- you know, I've been with you for a decade, so the answer is yes. I mean, listen, I -- when I was his economics advisor, very clear we want the tax reform to go to 28 percent, for corporate it's 25 percent for manufacturing. We will also -- we had a Republican Senate in the House, it had to be revenue neutral.

That was the only dialogue we ever had was revenue neutral. That being said, corporate tax reform is a good thing, I am not going to push back on that. I just think that we have not been in an environment with raising rates, high debt, fiscal deficit and think that's good for the stock market.

MCDOWELL: And I agree with you that we've never been an environment where the Federal Reserve. We had easy, such easy money for so long that we're entering this unprecedented era of where the Fed has to unwind this balance sheet where the easy money starts disappearing and you're just beginning to see the risky, even idiotic debts that people took because everything was going up in lockstep.

I want to get to this though Lindsey, just to mention that the Atlanta Federal Reserve did lower its first-quarter GDP forecast to four percent from 5.4 percent, that was what it released last week. The change in the space of a week, what do you make of it? BELL: I mean, it was related to consumption and fixed investment. So I think consumption is still good at 3 percent, we saw 3.8 percent in the fourth quarter, the consumer is very, very strong. And 4 percent, let's be honest, when was the last time we saw 4 percent GDP growth? That's an outstanding number. And the Atlanta Fed has been pretty decent about their -- with the accuracy for the initial estimate of GDP.

WOLF: We should ring the bell if we have four percent GDP.

BELL: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: And we're getting that four percent in part because of the tax reform.

WOLF: Yes.

MCDOWELL: There you go. See? We all agree.

WOLF: You got them two for two.

MCDOWELL: We all agree.

BELL: You don't have to worry about that deficit if we get (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: Again, I worry -- I've said this repeatedly but like you saw all the speculation going on in like Bitcoin in these assets, speculating with these exchange rate of products on stable low volatility markets and you get a snapback and you see what kind of risk people are taking. I don't think that this -- I mean, this clearly is not over with the loss on the Futures this morning.

Coming up, losing Wynn, real estate and casino mogul Steve Wynn stepping down from his own company after being accused of sexual misconduct allegations. What this means for the future of Wynn's global empire, that's ahead.

(VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Roaring toward a new chapter in the American space race, Elon Musk, Falcon Heavy makes history but he doesn't lose his sense of humor while doing it. We'll explain.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. Investors are strapping in for another busy day in the market. Take a look at the Dow Futures right now, 236-point gain on the Dow Futures. Volatility came back with a vengeance and the question remains: How long will it last? What kind of wild swings are we going to see in the market and what kind of losses it shakes out? And do some people lose confidence in their trading ability? Meantime, Steve Wynn now resigning as Chairman and CEO of Wynn Resorts. Cheryl Casone has more details -- Cheryl.

CASONE: That's right. Dagen, good morning. Wynn Resorts says that Steve Wynn's resignation is effective immediately, this comes after sexual misconduct allegations against the Las Vegas billionaire. A number of women claimed that Wynn harassed or assaulted them. One case led to $7.5 million settlement. Wynn denies these allegations but looking at what's happening in the premarket here, the stock is actually down almost 1-1/2 percent in the premarket. Again, Steve Wynn, his resignation effective immediately. So, we're also watching shares of Snap this morning. Get this, the stock soaring in the premarket up 23 percent, almost 24 percent. Well, there you go. Now, it's 24 percent. They reported better-than- expected quarterly results after the bell. The stock's back above that $17.00 IPO price for now. Revenues soaring more than 70 percent from a year ago. That a sharp increase in daily active users.

Also this morning, we're going to get earnings from Hasbro and Michael Kors, 21st Century Fox, the parent company of the FBN reports after the bell later today. And we are going to hear from Tesla, Elon Musk's company later today as well. And a little flicking for higher revenue from rising sales of their Model S, their Model X, and their Model 3 vehicles. Tesla shares, however, are having, of course of that earnings report, moving lower in the premarket a little more than a quarter percent. But let's stay with Tesla and Elon Musk, he made some news by launching the world's biggest rocket.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CROWD OF PEOPLE: Three, two, one.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Yes, SpaceX's Falcon Heavy launched yesterday to the delight of employees, space fans, of course. The 230-foot rocket featured 27 engines, three boosters. It cost SpaceX about a billion dollars to build. Now, two reusable side boosters did come back to Earth, they landed at the same time. That was flawless. Remember that saves your money in space travel. Now, this is neat though, Dagen, a Tesla Roadster was hidden onboard. It served as a test payload and they put basically a space guy in the driver's seat. The pictures have been amazing. That roadster has now exceeded Mars' orbit, but loving the pictures from there. And for any dame that may take a closer look at the Roadster, they're going to find this on the circuit board, quote, "Made on Earth by humans." So, we'll see if little space travel guy makes some alien friends while he's out there.

MCDOWELL: I love it.

CASONE: It was fun, right?

MCDOWELL: Yes, I was a NASA nerd when I was growing up. So, I love seeing these pictures in school, and Lea was a pilot.

GABRIELLE: This is one of those things that could have been like, massive success or a massive scale and what a massive success it was. I mean, looking at the two boosters land that way was just spectacular. And then - - I mean, really, that car is space trash, let's admit it. But if it's the first thing that we see just heading out into space like this, it's pretty neat to see this car cruising around.

MCDOWELL: Yes. And also, just the fact that you have private industries stepping up where the government has pulled away.

GABRIELLE: Well, that's just that. It's just that it's the way innovations do this.

WOLF: You're the expert in this space. I can just tell you, our pilots at our drone company in Washington were so pumped. It was like literally, you know, we shut down for the, you know, the hour it was on. I think they were waiting for two hours as well. But it was -- they were just so fired up.

BELL: I think watching the landing was so awesome, too.

GABRIELLE: Yes, it's one of those things where you just hold your breath. And you're hoping that it's going to all workout. But, you know, Dagen, you make such a good point about how innovation has changed and how defense used to lead innovation and now it's really industry that's leading innovation. And it's really, you know, it shows where our country can go and where we can develop things in the future.

MCDOWELL: Inspiring kids everywhere, including Disney battling on a galaxy far, far away to rocket to the Future, the earnings straight ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Disney CEO Bob Iger revealing the company's new ESPN streaming service will launch later this spring as Disney reports its first-quarter earnings. Lauren Simonetti has all the details.

SIMONETTI: What a report, Dagen. So, OK, stronger-than-expected profits, but taking a look here, you can see revenue $15.35 billion in the last quarter that actually missed expectations. And they did take a one-time benefit related to the new tax law. So, 1.6 billion there. Nonetheless, take a look at the share price reaction right now. Shares are up to 2.2 percent at 108.50 in the premarket. If you look at many of Disney's units and we get revenue for these segments, you can see that their studio and media units fell short of expectations, but they did see big strength in the theme parks. Goes to show you that customers are still willing to pay sky-high prices for tickets. By the way, we're going to find out of a price increase for theme park tickets in the coming week. You know, and the higher hotel prices consumers are willing to spend this for entertainment.

Speaking of, struggling ESPN but we do have news for ESPN. ESPN+, their new streaming service, it's going to debut in the spring. It's going to cost $4.99 a month. You can buy it as an add-on service and can be used for the redesigned ESPN App. It's basically going to give you live programming that's not available on the current channels. And then --

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KIT HARINGTON, ACTOR: Reach out.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Yes, that's "Game of Thrones" from HBO. And yes, the masterminds behind that hit series are teaming up with Disney and Lucasfilms to produce -- are you ready -- a new "Star Wars" series.
