And even more important than that is the investments that those corporations that companies all over America are going to be able to do right here in America as a result of the more competitive tax code.

MCDOWELL: Well, I just want to point out we're looking at the vast list of companies that are returning some of the tax savings to their workers whether it's in thousand dollar bonuses and we just found out Chipotle has said it's going to reinvest more than one-third of its savings from the new tax law in its employees. Some of the new benefits workers will get include one-time bonuses of up to $1000 to hourly and salaried workers along with life insurance, short-term disability insurance for hourly restaurant managers. This is just to name a few. But to look at thousand dollars in this country and say that it's pathetic crumbs, Josh, I don't -- I don't -- I know that that does not resonate with the American people. I've said this, are people really looking at their bigger paychecks thinking, I really wish Nancy Pelosi had her hands on this money instead of me.

BOLTON: Yes. I hope they are and comments like that I think just reflected a fundamental misunderstanding of what tax reform was likely to bring. And the evidence is now overwhelming. At the business roundtable alone we represent 200 of America's biggest corporations. We have members of our organization alone have already announced over $700 million in bonuses to their employees, lots of wage increases 401(k) enhancements. Those are real substantial benefits for the workers of all those corporations. And that's just in the first six weeks after the enactment of the tax reform. I think there is a lot more to come in this economy. Both in terms of short-term benefits that workers will realize more importantly in the long-term competitiveness of American companies which is where American workers need to work.

MCDOWELL: Josh, are you concerned though about the tax reform being part of the reason that we were -- we're going to have higher inflation? You talk about wage growth. But wage growth is part of the inflation equation, you wind up with higher interest rates. That is certainly last week was a big concern for the stock market with that wage growth number we got from the employment report.

BOLTON: Yes. That could have been a part of what's roiled the markets a bit in the -- in the last few days is an expectation now of some inflationary pressure from wage increases. But look, that's -- that wasn't the purpose of tax reform and it's not -- it's not really going to be the effect. What everybody across all political persuasions has been looking for is real wage increases for American workers. Tax reform is going to unleash a lot of that and overall that's a huge benefit to the American economy.

MCDOWELL: Josh, it was really good to see you. Thank you for being here as always.

BOLTON: Thanks for having me.

MCDOWELL: Josh Bolton. We will see you very soon. As we go to break, futures are trading like this right now, take a look. Dow futures were down more than 200 points when we started the show at 6:00 a.m. Eastern down 87 points right now. Wild swings on Wall Street, we will watch that as the day moves on. Plus, Tesla revving up to report fourth-quarter earnings after the bell. We break down the numbers ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. Welcome back, everybody. It's Wednesday, February 7th. Your top stories at 8:32 a.m. Eastern. Another wild day on Wall Street, the Dow Jones swimming more than 1000 points, almost 1200 points in fact from loss to highs in yesterday's session ending the day up 567 points, big bounce back from that kind of epic loss on Monday. The major market gages finishing yesterday in the green and the Dow, S&P, and NASDAQ are all back in positive territory for the year. Checking action this morning. Futures are off a little bit, the Dow futures are down 98 points, they were off more than 200 early in the morning about 6:00 a.m. when we started this program, started MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

But again, this is the issue, volatility is back, people have become very complacent, they weren't used to wild swings. The Dow had a move of one percent or more to seven times last year. Over in Europe, you have gains across the board to speak of. The biggest gainer there being the FTSE 100 in England up more than one percent. in Asia, markets were mostly lower, heavy selling to report on the KOSPI in South Korea down more than two percent.

Plus, Steve Wynn resigning from his namesake company. The casino mogul leaving amid allegations of sexual misconduct. Stuart Varney's take coming up. To the budget battle on Capitol Hill. One Senator unveiling legislation to cut back on government waste. The details ahead. Investors eyeing earnings of course back to fundamentals, Tesla gearing up to report after the closing bell, the numbers that you need to watch ahead. And going to a place where there are no roads.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: There might not be roads there but that didn't stop Elon Musk from sending a Tesla into space. More on the Falcon Heavy launch later this hour. Futures under pressure but well off the lows of the morning. We are -- what are the traders on Wall Street saying about this have crazy ride that we've seen really in the last week. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Nicole?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN HOST: Good morning, Dagen. So, obviously we've seen from choppy (INAUDIBLE) action, there's no doubt about that, even this morning as you have been covering there throughout the morning, we've seen it down as much as close to 300 -- and the futures now we're down about 100, so that's what the traders are talking about. They're also talking about the heavy volume that we saw yesterday. So there has been a lot of action and talking about the people who were trying to get in, there were some outages for people from T.D. Ameritrade and Fidelity trying to get -- try to navigate this difficult market. And whether or not the bottom is in. That's been a big topic of conversation. Yesterday we had obviously the second largest-point swing ever in history in the day before. The biggest ever. So, the question is whether or not the bottom is in and yesterday 75 percent they said is likely in. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Nicole, thank you so much for that. Nicole Petallides in the New York Stock Exchange. Turning to the shutdown showdown. A bipartisan budget deal in the works. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Minority Leader Chuck Schumer saying that they are very close to finalizing a budget that would boost military and nondefense spending, reportedly a total $143 billion. The new PAC makes no mention of immigration likely tabling that debate for now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SCHUMER: The Republican leader and I have been working together quite productively. Of course, there is still some outstanding issues to be resolved. But we are closer to an agreement than we have ever been.

MCCONNELL: Once we have established that the government is going to be open which needs to happen by February the 8th. We'll then go forward with an immigration debate.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining us now is Louisiana Senator John Kennedy. This plan comes just as the House approved a stopgap spending bill to fund the government through March 23rd. What do you think of the proposal from the leadership in the Senate?

SEN. JOHN KENNEDY (R), LOUISIANA: Well, I like the House deal, Dagen. I haven't seen the details of the leadership's proposal. They say they are close, I've been hearing that for four months. I've got to see it to believe it. I think if they make a deal it will be two-year deal and surprise-surprise they're going to increase spending. I just got to see how much and where they're going to spend the money. And how much is going to add to the he deficit and you can put me down as doubtful. I'm not saying I'm not going to vote for it, but every time there is a budget deal it always includes bigger numbers not smaller numbers and while you and I are talking today since we've been talking we've already borrowed a million-dollars. We've borrowed a million dollars a minute to operate the Federal government. $1.4 billion a day.

BELL: Senator, it's Lindsey Bell. I absolutely can appreciate your concern for the spending there and we need to cut back on some of these costs but isn't a two-year deal better than another C.R. to just get -- take us out another six weeks, by the time we get to march, the fiscal year only have six more months left.

KENNEDY: Well, the problem with the C.R. or continuing resolution, Dagen, is that there is no certainty and it does hurt our military. Because they can't plan. And I do support more spending for military. Every Senator, Republican and Democrat, has seen the classified information. They can't talk about it but they know we need more spending for the military. I just got to see how much of waste I've got to eat in order to help our military. And I can't make that determination until I see the -- see the numbers.

GABRIELLE: Senator, this is Lea Gabrielle. Nice to see you.

KENNEDY: Nice to see you, Lea.

GABRIELLE: It sounds like you're not very hot on what you expect to be coming your but also acknowledge that a C.R. is a terrible solution for what we have going on, so what are you proposing?

KENNEDY: Well, what I'm proposing is that we get serious about properly funding our military and we get serious about living within our needs. Nobody around here except some folks in the house and few Senators are talking about how we can spend less.

GABRIELLE: But how do you propose getting that done?

KENNEDY: Well, let me give you an example. I'm introducing the bill with Tom Carper, it's got a fancy title but I call it The Stop Paying Dead People Act. The federal government is paying I think between 10 and $20 billion dollars a year to dead people. And they're cashing the checks. Obviously, there is fraud. I mean in some states dead people can vote but cashing a check is a little bit too much.

WOLF: Senator --I

KENNEDY: I'll give you an example over a three-year period, the auditors found that the Federal government sent out $1 billion in foreign payments to dead farmers. There is another case over a five-year period, the Federal government paid $600 million in Federal pension checks to dead retirees. And the checks are being cashed and you know what's being done about it? Nothing, zero, nada.

MCDOWELL: Senator, I'm going to let Robert Wolf ask you a question but Robert, I think everybody is for getting rid of waste and fraud and paying dead people but a few billion dollars a year is a drop in the doggone bucket in terms of what we spend just on -- listen, the interest on our national debt in a year or two is going to top what we spend on the military, Robert.

WOLF: Yes. Senator Kennedy, I just want to shift quickly because it seems like either be a continuing resolution or a two-year budget deal with respect to the -- with respect to the Senate. It seems like there's not going to be a government shutdown. So I want to therefore just segue to DACA which market is a really big gate for these 800,000 immigrants waiting to see really what happens to them and just to be clear, you know, I'm a supporter to protect the DREAMers. And so I'm curious, where you are going to March 5th and how do you see the outcome for these individuals?

KENNEDY: Well, number one, there are a lot of meetings being held in groups of Senators are talking. But what counts is 60 votes. There are several plans on the table right now, every single one of them are held together with spit. The only way to find out where everybody stands is to vote. And what I expect Senator McConnell to do is put some sort of instrument bill on (INAUDIBLE) and let us start debating it and amending it. I'm much less sanguine than so my colleagues that we'll be able to 60 votes to do something meaningful. Our Democratic friends want amnesty and frankly nothing else. I want to solve the problem. I want to be here talking about another DACA immigrant amnesty issue five or 10 years from now.

MCDOWELL: But Senator, that's one of the reasons that they're including the people who never signed up for DACA, including the White House, including that in that 1.8 million people who would be given a pass to citizenship. So, do you oppose any path to citizenship whatsoever? You can call it amnesty --

KENNEDY: It just depends on the bill. Look, here is the problem. We've got immigration laws about half of our public officials don't agree with them so they don't enforce them. I give you ask sanctuary cities are exhibit number one. What we need to do is agree on a set of laws and enforce the damn things like every other country does. Just doing amnesty is not going to solve this problem. We need to --

WOLF: Just to shift. So we know it's coming up on March 5th, so there's not going to be a broad base immigration bill passed by March 5th, we know this. March 5th --

KENNEDY: No. We don't know that. Excuse me. But we don't know that.

WOLF: OK.

KENNEDY: We can start debating the immigration bill next week and come out with a comprehensive bill. We have 60 votes, now I'm not -- I don't think we will but we could --

WOLF: So let's agree that the likelihood is unlikely. So March 5th comes and we have the situation with the DREAMers. Where do you think it will -- what will happen on you March 5th? What is your expectation?

KENNEDY: Well, if we don't do anything by March 5th, it's up to the president. Because he controls the enforcement of deportation, he sets deportation policy.

MCDOWELL: Well, Senator --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- the DACA recipients that is being held up in the courts. So there is this feeling in Washington that they can drag their feet and wait on dealing with this because the court has said that the order to end DACA that they're basically put a stop to it at least in -- for -- at least temporarily.

KENNEDY: That's a very good point. I can just tell you categorical, unequivocally, I don't want there to be any doubt about where I stand. I'm not going to vote for amnesty unless I get a full bill that solves the problem. Now, you're going to ask me what that is, I've got my own ideas, I'm not so arrogant that I think only my ideas will work but I'm not just going to vote for amnesty and kick this problem down the road, I want to solve it.

MCDOWELL: Good to see you but everybody who you're in -- at the -- in the Senate and House with, you're kicking that debt problem down the road and it's going to blow up in everybody's face. That's my predictions. Senator John Kennedy.

KENNEDY: Amen, amen, sister, amen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Futures are off by 102 points, that's much better than the picture was at 6:00 a.m. Eastern Time. But again, wild swings on Wall Street yesterday. Meantime, Steve Wynn resigning as chairman and CEO of Wynn Resorts. Joining me now to weigh in is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Mr. Stuart Varney. What say you, sir?

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: Well, I don't think there was much choice here. I think Steve Wynn had to go. Look, he's been accused to buy, literally, dozens of women of sexual misconduct. He didn't get his day in court but that is not the point. Had this gone forward with him as CEO, the Chinese government may well have withdrawn the licenses which Steve Wynn has for his casinos in Macau. You withdraw those licenses in Macau and you have just about destroyed Wynn Casino, the stock. He still got 12 percent of it, but if you can operate in Macau and he's got 70 percent of his revenue come from Macau, you can't operate, period. He have to go even though he didn't get his day in court. That's my reading of it.

MCDOWELL: But day in court, Stuart, though, means -- I mean, due process, we all believe in that, right?

VARNEY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That it means it leaves the company opening an internal investigation with outside counsel to look into this, but I think when it comes to light that an individual -- and this is according to all reports in the Wall Street Journal -- Steve Wynn set up an LLC to pay one accuser, took steps to conceal $7-1/2 million settlement. It's those settlements that we all well know dupe people in, in terms of their employment.

VARNEY: Oh, you got a good point, Dagen. No question about it. I'm just a little uncomfortable with the current trend towards utter dismissal, total disgrace, you lose everything but you never get to plead your case in court. Now, in this particular instance, I can understand why not? But you know, we've gone a long way with this. I'm not -- I'm not criticizing the women who've come forward. I enthrall it.

MCDOWELL: Stuart, no, no, no --

VARNEY: I'm saying we better settle down a little here because maybe, in some cases, some injustice is being done.

MCDOWELL: It's not just men who are uncomfortable with some of this, it's women like myself who is very uncomfortable with that story told about -- Aziz, I'm sorry, the comedian about this date that he had been on, and it was a bad date, and he -- again, people's careers and lives are destroyed in some instances by based on one headline. Never read -- never reading the allegations. I just think that there is just -- there is definitely a brewing discomfort among both men and women about how these allegations are aired.

VARNEY: Well said. And there are no good answers here, period.

MCDOWELL: No.

VARNEY: None.

MCDOWELL: None. But we do want women to be heard, too.

VARNEY: We do, indeed. Absolutely, we do. Yes, of course.

MCDOWELL: Stuart, you're the best. Your show starts in exactly 10 minutes. There you go, Monday through Fridays, Stuart is all over this market. It is going to be incredible coverage as it is every day, Stuart Varney 9:00 a.m. Eastern.

Coming up, SpaceX successfully launching the Falcon Heavy rocket, sending a Tesla Roadster into outer space. More video that's out of this world, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: To quote Robert Wolf, so cool. 3, 2, 1 liftoff. SpaceX successfully launching the Falcon Heavy Rocket yesterday, capable of lifting up to 140,000 pounds, and now, holds the title of world's most powerful rocket. But how will Elon Musk auto company take off today? Tesla set to report fourth-quarter results after the bell. It's expected to post a loss for $3.10 a share, revenue on revenue $3.28 billion. Joining us now, ARK Invest Analyst, Tasha Keeney. Tasha, what are expectations for Tesla?

TASHA KEENEY, INVEST ANALYST, ARK: So, I think most investors are worried about the Model 3 production ramp cash burn. But from our perspective, you know, people are comparing Tesla to traditional auto companies. It's an autonomous car company. And once that switch is flipped, and these cars that are already on the road today become fully autonomous, they're going to become revenue-generating assets. So, from that perspective, we're happy that Tesla is spending money to get this off the ground because we think that opportunity is huge. We think the global market for autonomous driving, autonomous taxis could be around $10 trillion.

BELL: But they do have competition in this space, Waymo, Lyft, a whole slew of others. How sure are you that they're going to get there first and they're going to be the winners in this race?

KEENEY: They do have competition but what Tesla has is scale. So, every car that's on the road today is basically like a mini R&D center. It's gathering data that Tesla then uses to train its autonomous driving algorithms. And no other automaker has been able to do this, get cars on the road with that capability. So, this puts Tesla years ahead of others and, you know, yesterday, we heard on G.M.'s earnings call that they have about 100 test cars on the road. I mean, Tesla has thousands of cars. Think about that information and what it's capable of.

WOLF: So, being an old-school Wall Street guy, at what point do you get nervous about cash burn, and what -- this is much more like almost a biotech company?

KEENEY: Because it's being -- the cash burn has been getting worse each quarter. Yes, yes. So, to give you an idea of roughly what we expect in earnings from these vehicles, so right now, each car is generating about $3,000 worth of earnings for Tesla. We think once you turn that autonomous, that could be a net present value about over $80,000 per vehicle, and --

MCDOWELL: So, we've -- go ahead, finish your --

KEENEY: And, you know, so we're happy that they're spending money. I think we'd be happy if they raised another $20 billion to get this off the ground.

MCDOWELL: So, you get the Tesla in space but you also have the CEO Elon Musk, the founder of the company who's busy with all these other pursuits including SpaceX. Concerned.

KEENEY: That's a valid point. You know, I think Elon Musk is a really amazing person. We saw in this rocket launch, he is capable of making the impossible possible, and so, you know, while no one has achieved this feat yet, I wouldn't put it past him.

MCDOWELL: OK. Tasha, Tasha Keeney, thank you so much.

KEENEY: Thanks for having me. Final thoughts when we come back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Final thoughts. Lindsey?

BELL: Get ready for this political uncertainty to drive that volatility.

MCDOWELL: Robert?

WOLF: Congrats to the Eagles, great year for the Pats, and I've already moved to the Celtics.

MCDOWELL: Yes, I would, too. Lea?

GABRIELLE: Ask for a military parade, that you can see our ships on parade, our submarines on parade, our soldiers, our sailors, airmen, and marines around the world. From Stephen LeClair who's a former marine, he says he wants to spend time with his family on July 4th, not in a parade.

MCDOWELL: And I say to the Democrats, stop talking down the economy and essentially rooting for a downfall for the markets, bad for them. Stuart, over to you.

VARNEY: Oh, I'll take it, Dagen. Thank you very much, indeed. It is not over but is it calming down a bit? OK. I'm on dangerous ground.

END

RIVA GOLD, REPORTER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: The only things that are really still up here are the auto sector in Europe and Italian stocks, as well as tiny bit, is left of Hong Kong's gains.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Riva, thank you so much.

I'm much less sanguine than so my colleagues that we'll be able to 60 votes to do something meaningful. Our Democratic friends want amnesty and frankly nothing else. I want to solve the problem. I want to be here talking about another DACA immigrant amnesty issue five or 10 years from now.

MCDOWELL: But Senator, that's one of the reasons that they're including the people who never signed up for DACA, including the White House, including that in that 1.8 million people who would be given a pass to citizenship. So, do you oppose any path to citizenship whatsoever? You can call it amnesty --

KENNEDY: It just depends on the bill. Look, here is the problem. We've got immigration laws about half of our public officials don't agree with them so they don't enforce them. I give you ask sanctuary cities are exhibit number one. What we need to do is agree on a set of laws and enforce the damn things like every other country does. Just doing amnesty is not going to solve this problem. We need to --

WOLF: Just to shift. So we know it's coming up on March 5th, so there's not going to be a broad base immigration bill passed by March 5th, we know this. March 5th --

KENNEDY: No. We don't know that. Excuse me. But we don't know that.

WOLF: OK.

KENNEDY: We can start debating the immigration bill next week and come out with a comprehensive bill. We have 60 votes, now I'm not -- I don't think we will but we could --

WOLF: So let's agree that the likelihood is unlikely. So March 5th comes and we have the situation with the DREAMers. Where do you think it will -- what will happen on you March 5th? What is your expectation?

KENNEDY: Well, if we don't do anything by March 5th, it's up to the president. Because he controls the enforcement of deportation, he sets deportation policy.

MCDOWELL: Well, Senator --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- the DACA recipients that is being held up in the courts. So there is this feeling in Washington that they can drag their feet and wait on dealing with this because the court has said that the order to end DACA that they're basically put a stop to it at least in -- for -- at least temporarily.

KENNEDY: That's a very good point. I can just tell you categorical, unequivocally, I don't want there to be any doubt about where I stand. I'm not going to vote for amnesty unless I get a full bill that solves the problem. Now, you're going to ask me what that is, I've got my own ideas, I'm not so arrogant that I think only my ideas will work but I'm not just going to vote for amnesty and kick this problem down the road, I want to solve it.

MCDOWELL: Good to see you but everybody who you're in -- at the -- in the Senate and House with, you're kicking that debt problem down the road and it's going to blow up in everybody's face. That's my predictions. Senator John Kennedy.

KENNEDY: Amen, amen, sister, amen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Futures are off by 102 points, that's much better than the picture was at 6:00 a.m. Eastern Time. But again, wild swings on Wall Street yesterday. Meantime, Steve Wynn resigning as chairman and CEO of Wynn Resorts. Joining me now to weigh in is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Mr. Stuart Varney. What say you, sir?

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: Well, I don't think there was much choice here. I think Steve Wynn had to go. Look, he's been accused to buy, literally, dozens of women of sexual misconduct. He didn't get his day in court but that is not the point. Had this gone forward with him as CEO, the Chinese government may well have withdrawn the licenses which Steve Wynn has for his casinos in Macau. You withdraw those licenses in Macau and you have just about destroyed Wynn Casino, the stock. He still got 12 percent of it, but if you can operate in Macau and he's got 70 percent of his revenue come from Macau, you can't operate, period. He have to go even though he didn't get his day in court. That's my reading of it.

MCDOWELL: But day in court, Stuart, though, means -- I mean, due process, we all believe in that, right?

VARNEY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That it means it leaves the company opening an internal investigation with outside counsel to look into this, but I think when it comes to light that an individual -- and this is according to all reports in the Wall Street Journal -- Steve Wynn set up an LLC to pay one accuser, took steps to conceal $7-1/2 million settlement. It's those settlements that we all well know dupe people in, in terms of their employment.

VARNEY: Oh, you got a good point, Dagen. No question about it. I'm just a little uncomfortable with the current trend towards utter dismissal, total disgrace, you lose everything but you never get to plead your case in court. Now, in this particular instance, I can understand why not? But you know, we've gone a long way with this. I'm not -- I'm not criticizing the women who've come forward. I enthrall it.

MCDOWELL: Stuart, no, no, no --

VARNEY: I'm saying we better settle down a little here because maybe, in some cases, some injustice is being done.

MCDOWELL: It's not just men who are uncomfortable with some of this, it's women like myself who is very uncomfortable with that story told about -- Aziz, I'm sorry, the comedian about this date that he had been on, and it was a bad date, and he -- again, people's careers and lives are destroyed in some instances by based on one headline. Never read -- never reading the allegations. I just think that there is just -- there is definitely a brewing discomfort among both men and women about how these allegations are aired.

VARNEY: Well said. And there are no good answers here, period.

MCDOWELL: No.

VARNEY: None.

MCDOWELL: None. But we do want women to be heard, too.

VARNEY: We do, indeed. Absolutely, we do. Yes, of course.

MCDOWELL: Stuart, you're the best. Your show starts in exactly 10 minutes. There you go, Monday through Fridays, Stuart is all over this market. It is going to be incredible coverage as it is every day, Stuart Varney 9:00 a.m. Eastern.

Coming up, SpaceX successfully launching the Falcon Heavy rocket, sending a Tesla Roadster into outer space. More video that's out of this world, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: To quote Robert Wolf, so cool. 3, 2, 1 liftoff. SpaceX successfully launching the Falcon Heavy Rocket yesterday, capable of lifting up to 140,000 pounds, and now, holds the title of world's most powerful rocket. But how will Elon Musk auto company take off today? Tesla set to report fourth-quarter results after the bell. It's expected to post a loss for $3.10 a share, revenue on revenue $3.28 billion. Joining us now, ARK Invest Analyst, Tasha Keeney. Tasha, what are expectations for Tesla?

TASHA KEENEY, INVEST ANALYST, ARK: So, I think most investors are worried about the Model 3 production ramp cash burn. But from our perspective, you know, people are comparing Tesla to traditional auto companies. It's an autonomous car company. And once that switch is flipped, and these cars that are already on the road today become fully autonomous, they're going to become revenue-generating assets. So, from that perspective, we're happy that Tesla is spending money to get this off the ground because we think that opportunity is huge. We think the global market for autonomous driving, autonomous taxis could be around $10 trillion.

BELL: But they do have competition in this space, Waymo, Lyft, a whole slew of others. How sure are you that they're going to get there first and they're going to be the winners in this race?

KEENEY: They do have competition but what Tesla has is scale. So, every car that's on the road today is basically like a mini R&D center. It's gathering data that Tesla then uses to train its autonomous driving algorithms. And no other automaker has been able to do this, get cars on the road with that capability. So, this puts Tesla years ahead of others and, you know, yesterday, we heard on G.M.'s earnings call that they have about 100 test cars on the road. I mean, Tesla has thousands of cars. Think about that information and what it's capable of.

WOLF: So, being an old-school Wall Street guy, at what point do you get nervous about cash burn, and what -- this is much more like almost a biotech company?

KEENEY: Because it's being -- the cash burn has been getting worse each quarter. Yes, yes. So, to give you an idea of roughly what we expect in earnings from these vehicles, so right now, each car is generating about $3,000 worth of earnings for Tesla. We think once you turn that autonomous, that could be a net present value about over $80,000 per vehicle, and --

MCDOWELL: So, we've -- go ahead, finish your --

KEENEY: And, you know, so we're happy that they're spending money. I think we'd be happy if they raised another $20 billion to get this off the ground.

MCDOWELL: So, you get the Tesla in space but you also have the CEO Elon Musk, the founder of the company who's busy with all these other pursuits including SpaceX. Concerned.

KEENEY: That's a valid point. You know, I think Elon Musk is a really amazing person. We saw in this rocket launch, he is capable of making the impossible possible, and so, you know, while no one has achieved this feat yet, I wouldn't put it past him.

MCDOWELL: OK. Tasha, Tasha Keeney, thank you so much.

KEENEY: Thanks for having me. Final thoughts when we come back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Final thoughts. Lindsey?

BELL: Get ready for this political uncertainty to drive that volatility.

MCDOWELL: Robert?

WOLF: Congrats to the Eagles, great year for the Pats, and I've already moved to the Celtics.

MCDOWELL: Yes, I would, too. Lea?

GABRIELLE: Ask for a military parade, that you can see our ships on parade, our submarines on parade, our soldiers, our sailors, airmen, and marines around the world. From Stephen LeClair who's a former marine, he says he wants to spend time with his family on July 4th, not in a parade.

MCDOWELL: And I say to the Democrats, stop talking down the economy and essentially rooting for a downfall for the markets, bad for them. Stuart, over to you.

VARNEY: Oh, I'll take it, Dagen. Thank you very much, indeed. It is not over but is it calming down a bit? OK. I'm on dangerous ground.

END

RIVA GOLD, REPORTER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: The only things that are really still up here are the auto sector in Europe and Italian stocks, as well as tiny bit, is left of Hong Kong's gains.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Riva, thank you so much.

GOLD: Thanks for having me.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN HOST: And that is it for us. Over to Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo this morning. Hey Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Good morning ladies. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It is Wednesday, February 7th. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Volatility slamming Wall Street investors from Coast-to-Coast. They were in for a wild ride yesterday as the DOW finish the day up nearly 600 points after falling by about the same amount in earlier trading. All of the -- as of yesterday's close, all three of those major market gauges are back in positive territory for the year.

But Futures are telling a different story, 243 point loss on the DOW Futures this morning. Again, will volatility end this bull market coming on its nine-year anniversary next month, we will ask that question. Meantime, the economy still looks strong, the Atlanta Federal Reserve did lower its first-quarter GDP forecast to four percent, still hot but that's down from 5.4 percent last week.

In Europe, stocks are heading higher. We have some modest gains across the board in England, France, and Germany but in Asia overnight, stocks mostly lower. The Kospi in South Korea, the worst performer there. The Nikkei managing to eke out a small gain but the Kospi up by more than two percent.

The budget battles looming, lawmakers have until tomorrow night to reach an agreement to keep the federal government running as the House passes a stopgap spending bill, the fight now turns to the Senate where immigration remains a top issue. President Trump weighing in from the White House yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If we don't change it, let's have a shutdown, we'll do a shutdown and it's worth it for our country. I'd love to see a shutdown if we don't get this stuff taken care of.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The latest on the immigration battle ahead. Steve Wynn, out. The details as the billionaire mogul steps down as CEO of his company following sexual misconduct claims.

SpaceX takes it to infinity and beyond.

(VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The company launching their most powerful rocket since the Apollo mission. Sending a Tesla Roadster into orbit as well, more on the giant leap for the private space race ahead.

Plus, winter is coming to a galaxy far, far away. From ESPN to "Star Wars", the Disney earnings, a fan's dream. The new details on the company's fourth streaming service and its plans that came with the mind behind "Game of Thrones."

All that and so much more coming up this morning, FOX News Correspondent, Lea Gabrielle is here. FOX News Contributor, 32Advisors Founder and CEO and Former Economic Advisor to President Obama, Robert Wolf. And CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell. Good morning to everybody.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning.

ROBERT WOLF, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Great too.

MCDOWELL: This is when I'm very happy. We have some age on the panel, myself included because we remember what this kind of all feels it looks like.

WOLF: You know, I'm thinking that -- I think I was in middle school when we had this volatility.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Really?

WOLF: It's been like a -- let's be honest, outside of the dot-com bubble and the Asia crisis and the 2008 recession, we've kind of been on a three- decade, one directional ride. We haven't seen the 1,200 point swing, I can't remember.

MCDOWELL: We want to make it there, yes.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: I mean, it turns out the stock market actually goes down sometimes, right? It should be a really -- this should be a wakeup call for investors, retail investors especially. What do you have in your portfolio? You need to know.

MCDOWELL: Well I think that people already got a wakeup call Lindsey and we will talk about that with people betting on stable markets with these inverse volatility funds, a couple of them shutting down yesterday. We're talking about massive losses, so it's not just individuals, that some of the smartest minds, some of the smartest guys and gals in the room, again, also losing money.

GABRIELLE: And a lot of computers involved in what was going on, of course, to those algorithms have certainly changed how the work is being done.

WOLF: No question.

MCDOWELL: We're going to talk about it all this morning. Coming up, White House Director of Legislative Affairs, Marc Short is here. New York Congressman Tom Suozzi, New York Congresswoman, Claudia Tenney, that's on the left and the right, we'll have them on together. Louisiana Senator, John Kennedy, and former George W. Bush Chief of Staff Business Roundtable President and CEO, Josh Bolton.

You don't want to miss any of those guests but first for our top story, Wall Street bouncing back, U.S. markets rallying to regain almost half their losses from the day before when stocks took the largest plunge in six and a half years, that is the percentage loss that we saw on the DOW. The DOW ending the day with a gain of 567 points. After closing, down more than 1,100 points on Monday. Futures right now are showing losses across the board, 243 point loss on the DOW Futures.

Despite the turbulence, Treasury Secretary Steve MNuchin telling lawmakers on Capitol Hill that the markets are functioning, "Very well."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, U.S. TREASURY SECRETARY: We are very focused on the long- term economic growth and we believe that the policies that we've enacted including tax reform are very positive for a long-term economic growth. We're already beginning to see that in terms of corporate investments back into the United States and the impact on corporate earnings.

I think as you said that the stock market is up significantly over 30 percent since President Trump was elected, we're monitoring the stock markets, they're functioning very well, and we continue to believe in the long-term impact of the stock market.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Lindsey, your take on what Secretary MNuchin is saying but also in volatility going to threaten this nine-year bull market?

BELL: I think volatility certainly has a shot at ruining it but look, last year, there were eight days that we saw a move of one percent plus or minus on the S&P500. Historically, we usually see about 50 of those days. And when you have a year like that, the next year, you're bound to have more volatility. So, I think people should buckle in and get ready for more of that.

MCDOWELL: What all this referencing is, again, it was this sense of calm leads to overconfidence. Among individual investors and professional investors that people kind of become delusional about their ability and you had all these bets on stable markets, this inverse volatility.

These were exchange-traded retail products, two of which including the XIV closed down to investors after they lost most of their money of late Monday. So, again, these losses, the tide goes out and you see who was swimming naked.

WOLF: Well, I won't comment on the swimming naked but what I will say is we realize financial engineering doesn't always work and program trading sometimes the pendulum goes too far each lane, you have these types of swings.

My concerns are two-fold, one, I think the administration is talking way too much about the stock market. I think President Trump, I think he should take a lot of credit for the rally but to talk about it literally every day, it's not the gauge on the economy we should be using as 50 percent of the nation doesn't even own stocks.

MCDOWELL: Well I've been saying that literally since he took office.

WOLF: Well that's where I took it from. And I think secondly, I think that I know as the oldest one on this desk, I have not been in a market that we've seen this type of back up and rates starting, inflation feeling protectionist environment, problems with the fiscal deficit on one side, and then the other side, decent growth, you have the tax cuts that are going to be almost like its own quantitative easing and then lastly, good corporate profits. There's a real tug of war that's going to go in 2018.

MCDOWELL: Well who's going to win because I will push back because I've been concerned about interest rate moving up since really the end of last year but with inflation now come -- with wages now growing at close to three percent which happened in the most recent month.

That's -- still, wages are still -- growth is still very muted, inflation is still muted. And all the signs in the market, for the most part, do say that the economy is OK if not, great.

WOLF: So I would say -- first of all, I would say the bulls will win short-term because the tax reform is going to be the sugar candy for corporate growth. And I think you're going to see that short-term soft buybacks, dividend, some M&A activity.

But I think long-term, people are going to project out a backup of rates and when we start getting three and a half, four percent, you're going to see a shift take place from equity to fixed income, you're just going to see it because risk free returns are going to start to look good versus a market that's been pretty buoyant. I mean, that's just one thing I do have as experience 30 years. I can't say how much in the market today.

MCDOWELL: It sounds like you're calling longer term for a bear market in stocks and bonds because, again, if -- because we've had a bull market in bonds since the early 1980s. Did you --

WOLF: I wouldn't say a bear market but I think the bears will beat the bulls probably come towards late 2018, early 2019 as we see in just to my opinion this nervousness. We're going to do better, growth is here, wages will do better, the labor force is starting to tighten. Those are just facts. And we have a whole new Fed environment with Powell coming in.

BELL: I think it's going to depend largely on inflation and interest rates as well and inflation is going to be driven by that wage number. If we get productivity which it seems like we should get better productivity, the inflation won't come in high-speed manner that is sort of expected kind of market right now.

GABRIELLE: Any concerns about the impact to the economy because of tax reform if the Fed ends up tightening at monetary policy because of inflation as some are talking about right now and also -- MCDOWELL: Well they are tightening monetary policies. They're reducing their balance sheets, it's already down to $4 trillion and they're already raising interesting rates.

GABRIELLE: Right. But the question is, if interest rates if we get four instead of three, if things change as they are trying to cool down the economy getting too heated up, do you have any concerns over the tax cuts and how that might have an impact on the deficit and debt?

WOLF: Well I do. I mean, I've been speaking about it, yes, I'm a pro- growth Democrat but I have been -- I am fiscally pretty hawkish in a sense that I think if everything should have been revenue neutral, I believe in the PAYGO system. And so my view is although I was supportive of tax reform, I probably would have looked to have done -- I would have done it - -

MCDOWELL: So you were up -- so you were concerned that that --

WOLF: I was concerned on the fiscal side sometimes.

MCDOWELL: Well -- so you were also concerned when the national debt doubled under President Obama.

WOLF: Absolutely.

MCDOWELL: Did you fell in that as his economic advisor?

WOLF: We're talking about -- we're looking -- the answer -- you know, I've been with you for a decade, so the answer is yes. I mean, listen, I -- when I was his economics advisor, very clear we want the tax reform to go to 28 percent, for corporate it's 25 percent for manufacturing. We will also -- we had a Republican Senate in the House, it had to be revenue neutral.

That was the only dialogue we ever had was revenue neutral. That being said, corporate tax reform is a good thing, I am not going to push back on that. I just think that we have not been in an environment with raising rates, high debt, fiscal deficit and think that's good for the stock market.

MCDOWELL: And I agree with you that we've never been an environment where the Federal Reserve. We had easy, such easy money for so long that we're entering this unprecedented era of where the Fed has to unwind this balance sheet where the easy money starts disappearing and you're just beginning to see the risky, even idiotic debts that people took because everything was going up in lockstep.

I want to get to this though Lindsey, just to mention that the Atlanta Federal Reserve did lower its first-quarter GDP forecast to four percent from 5.4 percent, that was what it released last week. The change in the space of a week, what do you make of it? BELL: I mean, it was related to consumption and fixed investment. So I think consumption is still good at 3 percent, we saw 3.8 percent in the fourth quarter, the consumer is very, very strong. And 4 percent, let's be honest, when was the last time we saw 4 percent GDP growth? That's an outstanding number. And the Atlanta Fed has been pretty decent about their -- with the accuracy for the initial estimate of GDP.

WOLF: We should ring the bell if we have four percent GDP.

BELL: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: And we're getting that four percent in part because of the tax reform.

WOLF: Yes.

MCDOWELL: There you go. See? We all agree.

WOLF: You got them two for two.

MCDOWELL: We all agree.

BELL: You don't have to worry about that deficit if we get (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: Again, I worry -- I've said this repeatedly but like you saw all the speculation going on in like Bitcoin in these assets, speculating with these exchange rate of products on stable low volatility markets and you get a snapback and you see what kind of risk people are taking. I don't think that this -- I mean, this clearly is not over with the loss on the Futures this morning.

Coming up, losing Wynn, real estate and casino mogul Steve Wynn stepping down from his own company after being accused of sexual misconduct allegations. What this means for the future of Wynn's global empire, that's ahead.

(VIDEO CLIP)
