Penney Shares Tumble; Ringing In The New Year2018-12-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:15ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTDavid Kudla, Christopher Bedford, Yannick BenjaminNEWSFinancial122801cb.231Wild Trading Hits Markets; 2018 Business in Review; Shutdown Showdown; Bloomberg Reportedly Could Spend Over $100 Million on 2020 Campaign; 2020 Democratic Contenders; Blown Transformer In Queens; Alabama Disinformation Campaign; Reid Hoffman Apology; Sears Liquidation Fears; J.C. Penney Shares Tumble; Ringing In The New YearLauren Simonetti, Kristina Partsinevelos, Kat Timpf, John Layfield, Marie Harf, Adam Klotz

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I didn't fill up my coffee cup, that's about --

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Oh, I can bring you one.

SIMONETTI: -- that's about all that you missed. You don't have any time, girl, you're busy today. All right. Good morning, everybody, I am Lauren Simonetti in for Maria Bartiromo. It is Friday, December 28th, here are you top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern Time.

Wall Street is looking to extend gains to day number three, Futures this morning sharply higher, Dow gaining a hundred and twenty-three, half of one percent, similar percentage gains across the board, this after a roller coaster session for the markets yesterday. Get this, the Dow swung more than 850 points during the session, finishing higher more than one percent. The S&P 500 picking up nearly one percent, the NASDAQ tacking on just over a third of one percent.

Council of Economic Advisers Chairman, Kevin Hassett, saying the President is happy with the economy going into the end of the year.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN HASSETT, COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISERS CHAIRMAN: I think the President thinks that the economy the -- is doing well, that the economic fundamentals are sound, and I think he's very pleased to see that the markets are moving back to sort of where they belong given the fundamentals.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Seeing follow-through in Europe, gains across the board, 1.8 percent to the upside for all three markets on your screen. Asian markets mostly higher as well. The Nikkei, the outlier here, it is down a third of one percent, and negative for the first time on a year in seven years.

Well, day number seven of the government shutdown in Washington and it does not look like it will end before the New Year. Meanwhile, a new poll shows more Americans blaming President Trump for the government shutdown. We're going to break it all down for you.

Then outside, there is some wicked weather, millions of Americans hit by blizzard conditions and we'll tell you where this storm is heading next. Plus, did you look outside? Blue skies at night in New York. We have the details on what exactly what happened and more of this pretty incredible yet beautiful video. Aliens? Maybe. All right. It's deadline day for Sears, the struggling retailer has until the end of today to find a bidder for its assets or it could disappear entirely.

All of that coming up with me and this morning, we also have FOX News Contributor and "GREG GUTFELD SHOW" Correspondent, and National Review Reporter, that is one big title, Kat Timpf, in white, Beyond Sport Global Ambassador and FOX News Contributor, John Layfield, and Former State Department Spokesperson and Co-host of "BENSON & HARF" on FOX News Radio, Marie Harf. Happy Friday.

KAT TIMPF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Happy Friday.

MARIE HARF, FOX NEWS RADIO HOST: Happy Friday.

SIMONETTI: What a strange week.

HARF: Yes. I mean what a way to end the year. So many ups and downs and it just feels like the news hasn't stopped at all.

SIMONETTI: I know. Are we ending the year up or down, though? What do you guys think?

TIMPF: I have no -- both.

HARF: It's a roller coaster.

JOHN LAYFIELD, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes, I think both -- I think is safe to say.

HARF: Yes.

SIMONETTI: I think everybody is going to need a glass of champagne on New Year's Eve, right? Or --

TIMPF: At least one.

LAYFIELD: Or just a shot of whiskey.

HARF: Just one.

LAYFIELD: Only (INAUDIBLE)

SIMONETTI: And just -- and then you just see that veteran then you can live to a hundred and twelve years old. That lives a hundred and twelve --

TIMPF: Exactly.

LAYFIELD: That's right.

SIMONETTI: - by smoking cigars and drinking whiskey. Anyway, all right. Also coming up this morning, Wells Fargo Investment Institute Senior Global Equity strategist, Scott Wren, Ohio Congressman, House Ways and Means Committee member and Iraq War Veteran, Brad Wenstrup, former CKE Restaurant CEO and Former Labor Secretary Nominee, Andy Puzder, and Texas Congressman, Medical Doctor, and member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Michael Burgess. You don't want to miss it, and we're -- we got a lot to discuss and we're going to start with our top story this hour, and that is the market.

Once again, front and center, but it's a good day today or at least it's shaping up to be after a wild day of trading on Wall Street. Yesterday, the Dow staging a late comeback, swinging more than 850 points from high to low, and that's been what we've seen the past six sessions. We've seen one percent plus moves in both directions for the Dow Jones Industrial Average, let's talk about it and bring in the founder, CEO, and Chief Investment Strategist at Mainstay Capital Management, David Kudla. David, good morning.

DAVID KUDLA, CEO, MAINSTAY CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: Good morning, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: What do you make of the volatility?

KUDLA: Well, it has been quite extreme in the past week, in the past month, and really the past quarter. It is what we expect now going into 2019. We had it very nice in 2017, the first part of 2018, but we've seen extreme volatility pick up through all of this year and this is what we need to expect more of. And a lot of it is because there's this confusion or maybe a seeking of what is the economic outlook for next year.

We had as little as a month and a half ago people thinking that the -- we - - the Federal Reserve might hike four, five -- even five times next year. That went down to maybe a couple of times. Now the Fed Futures prediction of how much the Fed will raise next year is showing us that they wouldn't raise at all. But the Fed dot plot, their own forecast, shows two raises and those that think that we're headed for recession. So, we have this very divergent view about the economy --

SIMONETTI: Uh-hmm.

KUDLA: And that is causing a lot of volatilities as we move between those different views.

SIMONETTI: Yes. It's true. Wall Street thinks one thing, they are suspecting or predicting a sharp slowdown in the New Year. And Main Street might think the opposite. Kevin Hassett was on after the bell yesterday, and he said, you know, Wall Street does engage all the momentum that we're seeing. In the economy, small businesses are not part of Wall Street and they're doing great right now.

KUDLA: Yes. If you -- if we look at the consumer, which is two-thirds of our economy and just look at the holiday spending season, look at the fourth quarter, we look at November retail sales, October revised higher, the --

SIMONETTI: Uh-hmm.

KUDLA: -- holiday shopping season from November 1st through December 24th, best in six years.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

KUDLA: Amazon having record sales.

SIMONETTI: But consumer confidence was down two months in a row. Sorry to interrupt you, David, but we do have that number, that it fell two months in a row. What do you make of that?

KUDLA: Well, that's a lagging indicator and a lot of that is a result of what's happened in the stock market over the past quarter. And so we'll see some of those -- the soft data like that will soften as the wealth effect or lack thereof, kicks in of what the stock market's been doing. But, you know, we're looking at two to two and a half percent growth next year, not a recession.

Unemployment, it's still near a 49-year low, and, you know, we just don't think a recession is right around the corner, we think the economy is still doing quite well. I think the biggest thing for the stock market is where do corporate earnings really come in? We think that we can still get eight or nine percent earnings growth in the fourth quarter, but -- or in the -- throughout 2019, but there are those that think that earnings are going to fall off a cliff.

If that's the case, we have trouble. If earnings, you know, we can't match the record earnings that we had in 2018, but if we get decent earnings in 2019, just eight or nine percent, we don't even need multiple expansion, we can do OK. Stocks can do OK through 2019.

LAYFIELD: David, if you go from say 20 percent right now in corporate earnings to about eight or nine percent, I think the estimate right now, consensus is around seven percent, so eight or nine would be a little bit higher than that, that is not falling off a cliff, as you say, but that doesn't pretend itself to the volatility that we've seen. Is this volatility really on different views of the economy? And what's going to happen next year or is it about the things the market can't control like Brexit, like this trade warm and so many things that's going on with these capricious politicians we have around the globe?

KUDLA: Yes, it -- you know, when we look at -- when we look abroad, when we look at Europe, whether it's yellow vest in France, whether it's Brexit, the problems in England, whether it's Italy arguing with the E.U. about future, you know, Europe has a lot of problems and we're avoiding Europe. We have this year for the last three quarters and will be going into 2019 because of the problems there, we're staying with U.S. stocks, we're starting to look at emerging markets but, yes, that's --

You know, we do have a lot of anxiety indigestion for the markets that's coming from D.C.

SIMONETTI: Uh-hmm.

KUDLA: And recently, the China-U.S. trade issues are a concern because that's where government action does affect real economies, and affects the stock market, so how that all works itself out in the New Year will definitely matter.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

KUDLA: But, you know, it is -- we look -- as we look further into the year, you know, it'll be a function of how -- when do we get into the first quarter? What do those corporate earnings start to look like?

SIMONETTI: David, the Wall Street Journal is out with the story titled "The Investment That Cost Apple $9 billion in 2018 and it references the effect, market prices have had on company's decisions to buy back their stocks, specifically Apple.

Buy backs have helped support the market. Do you think we're going to see companies then buying this dip?

KUDLA: We've seen a little bit of that, you know. The funny thing about stock buybacks by corporations is they tend to buy high and that's not because they don't know when to buy stocks, it's more a function of the reason or their -- or their ability to buy -- to initiate those buybacks, it's typically when the economy is doing well, when the company is doing well because they're buying that with a free cash flow so they tend to initiate more stock buybacks during good economic times when they high revenue, high profits, high free cash flow. So, they tend to be buying high, not buying low.

There have been some companies step in with stock prices lowered and initiate stock buyback programs here late in the year.

SIMONETTI: Uh-hmm.

KUDLA: But, you know, if we do see more of an economic slowdown next year, we could see that. This year with the Corporate Tax Reform and the strong economy, we had over one trillion, a new record, in stock buybacks in 2018.

SIMONETTI: Are you concerned at all about companies and the amount of cash that they're holding and also we saw the Steven Mnuchin, the now infamous call to the banks earlier this week, considered their about ability to lend, are you -- are you concerned about any of these things?

KUDLA: No, you know, a lot of us were left scratching our heads why that letter was sent out, why those calls were made to the bank. There wasn't a concern about liquidity. We think that was a reason for some of the market volatility on Monday, on Christmas Eve, because that probably wasn't needed and what we've seen though is maybe a sturdier hand now. I think the more amicable tone of President Trump towards Jay Powell at the Fed --

SIMONETTI: Yes.

KUDLA: -- comments that --

SIMONETTI: Well, do you think there's a face-to-face meeting between the President and Jay Powell? Because that's what's been reported as a possible. Would that help the market's sentiment right now?

KUDLA: I think it absolutely would. And they say it's going to happen, I hope it happens because, you know, the fact that they're just meeting face- to-face and talking will be better than comments over Twitter and however else because --

SIMONETTI: Yes.

KUDLA: -- it's not doing the markets any good.

SIMONETTI: So the theme of 2019 then is going to be talking, whether it's Trump and Powell, or Trump and President Xi of China, just talking will get these markets to go up, I suppose. David Kudla, thank you so much for joining us on this Friday.

KUDLA: Thank you.

SIMONETTI: All right. Coming up, a wicked winter storm pushing its way to the east, how millions of Americans in the path will be affected this weekend and it's not aliens. The internet going crazy over these mysterious blue lights above New York City, we're going to tell you what caused the sky to light up. Is that blue or green? Blue green?

TIMPF: Blue.

SIMONETTI: Teal? Blue? OK.

SIMONETTI: Markets still up with about three hours before the opening bell, but we have half the gains that we saw earlier, Dow Futures higher by 66 points. They were up about a hundred and forty just moments ago. The byline right now on the Wall Street Journal, Blue Chips log a record rebound yesterday after the week's biggest point in gain the day before, so volatility is the name of the game. We'll see.

Speaking of extreme, it's outside, too. We're watching the weather for you this morning. The Midwest taking hit by heavy snow while the East Coast is gearing up for flash floods. FOX News Meteorologist, Adam Klotz, live in the weather center with the bad news. Good morning, Adam.

ADAM KLOTZ, FOX NEWS METEOROLOGIST: Hey there, good morning, Lauren. You know what, it's that same snow system that's bringing all the heavy rain now to portions of the east. The East Coast and South East (INAUDIBLE) already stretching all the way back actually to New Orleans up through Atlanta and then all its way up to New York in the next couple of hours. Now the backside of this system is still producing a little bit of snow, enough snow that we still have some blizzard watches warnings, winter advisory stretching across portions of the Upper Midwest, this is going to be kind of moving out of the area within the next couple of hours so really winding down.

The worst of the snow in this area has moved off and it becomes more of a rain event. This entire system is running into some very warm air. You'll see it here in our future radar and you can pay attention to the timestamp kind of back behind my head, but it runs up throughout the day here on Friday and early Saturday morning, rain eventually heavy at times stretching from D.C. up to New York, up to Boston, colder air on the backside of this, but you noticed it was all just that heavy rain. Wouldn't be a surprise if there was some flooding especially in the southeast with this.

We've already seen a couple of inches of rain in Atlanta here early this morning. But all this moisture is running into some very warm air. Again, cold on the backside so where it's snowing, temperatures are still back down into the 20's, you get far enough behind it, and you see some spots down into single digits, but currently on the East Coast, it is well above our seasonal averages, as you're looking at 56 degrees here in New York City, 70 degrees in Raleigh. This continues. It stays warm throughout the entire day here on Friday, warm into Saturday.

Now there is cold air behind the system, so once this moves off coast, it cools down a little bit for us on Friday -- or on Sunday, excuse me, but then we warm back up on Monday and Tuesday, which means by the time we get into the New Year or close to the New Year, New Year's Eve, 47 degrees is the high there for New Year's Eve. It -- actually, by the time the ball drops, it'll only be down close to 40 degrees.

So, Lauren, it is going to be a mild start to this New Year even though we're talking about a big snowstorm in the middle of the country.

SIMONETTI: And if you're in Times Square, that's a lot of people probably going to, you know, enjoy the nice weather.

KLOTZ: Yes. It was like --

SIMONETTI: Uh-hmm.

KLOTZ: -- negative four last year, so this is better.

SIMONETTI: Oh. That's right.

KLOTZ: Yes.

SIMONETTI: Adam, thank you.

KLOTZ: Uh-hmm.

SIMONETTI: Kat Timpf, you plan to spend New Year's right in Times Square, right?

TIMPF: Not this year, no.

SIMONETTI: What are you guys doing?

TIMPF: I did last year when it was below zero for FOX and I couldn't feel my feet. Richard Fowler had to kind of drag me back to the van because I couldn't walk. It was so cold.

SIMONETTI: It was crazy. Yes.

TIMPF: Yes, it was nuts. What about you? What are you doing for New Year's?

HARF: I'm going to Northern New Hampshire, so it's going to be very cold and I hope a lot of snow.

SIMONETTI: And you're headed south, sort of?

LAYFIELD: I'm headed south to see my dad today and then come back to D.C. for New Year's Eve.

SIMONETTI: I can't believe. This is, like, it. Monday is New Year's Eve.

HARF: I know. I can't.

SIMONETTI: Wow. It always happens so fast.

HARF: 2019 is here.

SIMONETTI: It's been a full year, a wild year, especially on Wall Street. Maria Bartiromo is going to wrap up the highs and the lows of the year in business for us in just a bit. Plus it is deadline day for Sears. The retailer is bankrupt, it needs to find a buyer for its assets by the end of the day today or face liquidation. They'll sell the --

SIMONETTI: Roller coaster year for business. Maria Bartiromo takes a look back at the highs and lows of 2018.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: The year in business will likely go down, remembered mostly of how it's ending, with head-spinning moves in the stock market and uncertainty gripping the globe. The stock market rocked with wild moves up and down, but sadly for investors, it's been more down than up.

In Europe, Brexit on the brink.

THERESA MAY, PRIME MINISTER OF THE UNITED KINGDOM: I continue to believe that we can leave with a good deal and that is it.

BARTIROMO: Paris in pieces. Citizens rioting over a new gas tax designed to curve carbon emissions, all this as America's economy is humming in ways not seen in years. The President's tax plan kicking in January 1st, helping to send second quarter GDP north of four percent, and the unemployment rate all the way down to 3.7 percent.

STEVEN MNUCHIN, UNITED STATES TREASURY SECRETARY: The fact that a business can write off 100 percent of an investment is an enormous incentive to get people to make capital investment and that capital investment creates more jobs.

LARRY KUDLOW, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL: Blue-collar workers having their best increase in many, many years. The American economy is crushing it.

BARTIROMO: But the euphoria faded by midyear as the President's America First Policy meant renegotiating old trade deals. President Trump telling me in April that the United States will not back down until it has better terms with the rest of the world, notably China.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We're going --

BARTIROMO: Are you going to back down on the tariffs against China?

TRUMP: No, no, no. No. China wants to make a deal and so do I, but it's got to be fair deal for this country.

BARTIROMO: The administration calling out China over I.P. theft, the forced transfer of technology, spying on Americans and lopsided protectionist tariffs. But while doing so, global growth worries persisted. President Trump also calling out his own Federal Reserve Chairman for raising interest rates.

TRUMP: I think the Fed is making a mistake. They're so tight. I think the Fed has gone crazy.

BARTIROMO: Higher rates and the China tensions roiling the equity markets by years end with a big hit in the fourth quarter. The business world also still roiled by the Me Too Movement, including media mogul Les Moonves of CBS, fired and deprived of a massive severance package after an investigation uncover years of alleged sexual harassment.

It was also a year of big challenges for big tech.

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK: We didn't take a broad enough view of our responsibility. It was my mistake and I'm sorry.

BARTIROMO: The Facebook-Cambridge Analytica data scandal revealed that Cambridge Analytica took the personal data of millions of people's Facebook's profiles without their consent. And it was used for political purposes. Facebook stock taking a beating and others such as Google under the microscope for privacy issues, leading to call for tighter regulations.

2018 saw a big change for the internet, if you noticed, net neutrality was repealed by the Trump Administration. Despite promises of doom, the internet seems to work the same as before. But it is not the same as before for believers of Bitcoin. A year ago, the cryptocurrency riding high near $20,000, but by year-end crashing below 5,000. The year-end Midterm Election set the tone for the year ahead with new uncertainty with the Democrats in the majority in the House, creating new questions over what can get done legislatively.

TRUMP: I am proud to shut down the government for border security.

BARTIROMO: 2019 begins with a new Congress and a divided government. That traditionally has been good for business in the stock market. No wonder the list of IPOs ready to launch is growing. But the U.S. will need to ratify the new trade deal with Mexico and Canada, as well as finish its work with China among other things.

And in this era of a nontraditional precedent where business and politics overlap, you can be sure that more surprises are in store for the New Year.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: So bottom lining that, 2018 was the year of the big surprise in my opinion.

HARF: Absolutely.

TIMPF: Right.

HARF: And we're one year out basically from the tax cuts having taking effect. We're seeing the impact of that sort of a mixed bag as we look back on those tax cuts. Corporate profits are up, some workers got benefits, some plants have kept closing like in my home state of Ohio, Lordstown, Ohio.

SIMONETTI: Oh.

HARF: So that's a big one. That's going to be a big issue seeing how these tax cuts play out over the next few months. Also as Maria mentioned, trade and NAFTA, new Congress coming in, it is not a given that they will approve the new NAFTA. I think it's likely, but it's not a given and so that will be another political fight and, of course, China trade. This is the big ticket item the President has to get something done on. I think his supporters who are impacted, soybean farmers, steel producers, they've been willing to give him some leeway here sometime, but I don't think it's indefinite. So, as we look to 2019, that time may run out --

SIMONETTI: Yes.

HARF: -- at some point.

SIMONETTI: We do have hope there's going to be a January sit-down --

HARF: That's right.

SIMONETTI: -- between both sides, Washington and Beijing, to try to get something done --

LAYFIELD: Yes.

SIMONETTI: -- as the 90-day trade truce that expires in March is -- that clock is ticking.

LAYFIELD: Yes. And you look at the take from Maria, you had a market that was doing pretty well the first six months, and all of a sudden this trade war kicks in.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

LAYFIELD: And you have so much unpredictability and so much volatility, it started from that point. I think Brexit right here is underestimated. I think Brexit next year could fall completely apart.

SIMONETTI: David Kudla --

LAYFIELD: I think --

SIMONETTI: -- said he's not touching Europe.

LAYFIELD: I think the E.U. could fall apart. If Brexit is a hard Brexit, then E.U. -- then Italy will probably drop out of the E.U. as well and the E.U. dissolves. That is big deal going on in Europe and that is not priced in on the market yet.

SIMONETTI: That is very interesting call because we're fixated on the Federal Reserve and the status of Jay Powell, and what's going on with China as being our two biggest headwinds, but Brexit and --

LAYFIELD: It's all things you can't --

SIMONETTI: -- two countries perhaps going out of the E.U.

LAYFIELD: That's right. And the whole E.U could dissolve on that. If England -- if U.K. has to stay in, that will send a message to Italy, "You got to get your debt under control," Italy will probably rein in its debt and stay in the E.U. If Brexit is a hard Brexit, which looks like it certainly could be --

SIMONETTI: Yes.

LAYFIELD: -- I think Italy drops out as well.

SIMONETTI: They never plan for the hard Brexit. That was the problem. Anything to add?

TIMPF: I just think it's been crazy to see everything that's happened with Facebook this year.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

TIMPF: I think they've had such a bad year, and now Google, too, with all the privacy stuff.

SIMONETTI: Are you still on Facebook?

TIMPF: I'm still on Facebook, yes, but I'm concerned about some of my private messages, the fact that people have read those, I mean you don't think about it -- you don't really think about it. You think of it as being, "Oh, private message?"

SIMONETTI: Nothing's private.

TIMPF: "It's a private message," but nothing's private. There's no such thing.

SIMONETTI: All right.

HARF: Yes.

SIMONETTI: Coming up, the shutdown showdown in Washington and right now no end in sight, we're going to take a look at what could happen when Democrats take control of the House next week and blue skies at night. What caused this stunning blue scene over New York City late last night? We missed it. We were sleeping.

SIMONETTI: Welcome back. I'm Lauren Simonetti, in for Maria Bartiromo, this morning. It is Friday, December 28th, your top stories at 6:30 a.m. Eastern Time.

Wall Street pulling away from premarket highs up actually, look at this, volatility reign supreme, we're up just 60, now, we're up about 200 points on the Dow. So it could be another good day, but of course, everything can change come 3:00 p.m., in that final hour.

A wild session for the major averages yesterday, the Dow swinging more than 850 points during the session, it did finish higher by more than one percent, the S&P 500 picked up just about a percent, and the NASDAQ tacked on just over a third of one percent.

Take a look at European indices, this morning. Green across the board, London, Paris, and Frankfurt, all up 1.8 percent. Asian markets, mostly higher overnight, the Nikkei however, down a third of a percent.

The border battle heating up with the government shutdown, now, in day seven, and President Trump doubles down on his call for the border wall, after an alleged cop-killer in California was in the U.S., illegally, the fallout, ahead.

Then, blue skies over New York, but it was night time, we have the details on what exactly happened and more of this incredible video.

Plus, it's deadline day for Sears, the struggling iconic retailer has until the end of today, to find a bidder for its assets or it could disappear entirely.

And we're ringing in the New Year in style, we've got the top wine choices to help you celebrate 2019, all that coming up.

Our top story this half hour, is the shutdown showdown, the partial government shutdown most likely stretching into 2019 with no clear end in sight, even some of the President's closest allies are losing hope of a quick agreement to end the shutdown.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. MARK MEADOWS (R-NC), CHAIR OF THE HOUSE FREEDOM CAUCUS: Having discussions with the President prior to the Christmas break, he was fully engaged in making a number of different options available to Democrats, and yet, it's been met with really just resistance and no acceptance whatsoever.

As you know, they've now said that we're not going to have votes this week, here in the house, so any suggestion that this would end quickly, are quickly fading.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: This comes as a new Reuters poll shows the majority of Americans blame President Trump for the shutdown, while only 33 percent blamed the Democrats in Congress.

Joining me now is Daily Caller News Foundation Editor-in-Chief, Christopher Bedford, Chris, good morning.

CHRISTOPHER BEDFORD, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, DAILY CALLER NEWS FOUNDATION: Good morning.

SIMONETTI: Does it matter who we blame? It matters the solution here, right?

BEDFORD: Yes, it doesn't really matter that much who you blame, we're two years away from anybody voting, and despite everyone in Washington, always freaking out over poll this or poll that, when the government shuts down, it doesn't seem to have a huge electoral effect, with that -- except with the major -- possible exception of a Virginia election a few years ago, when Virginia was so heavily affected by the shutdown.

SIMONETTI: The President could have gotten some support for his border wall and the need to contain and stop illegal immigration, with the news coming out of Northern California, that an illegal immigrant killed a legal immigrant, that police officer originally from Fiji. Does that aid his push?

BEDFORD: It might aid a little bit, at least, in the hearts and minds of Americans. This is a classic story, a very tragic story of an immigrant from Fiji, who comes here and joins a law enforcement agency, he's serving and protecting and he's got a 5-month-old child and a wife, and he's shot by someone who's here, illegally, when he pulls him over for suspected drunk driving.

That's a really tragic story on Christmas week, and it's a kind of story that says it paints a difference between those who come here, legally, and try to help, and try to serve their community, and those who don't, and they live in the shadows and they break the law.

And while there are some people that aren't shooting police officers, obviously, it shows you the worries here, but the problem is, the Democrats have no incentive here to give the President a win on anything. They were sailing into this, thinking that the President was going to fold on his campaign promise for a border wall, about two weeks ago.

Now, it's looking like he's not going to. But Democrats, their voters will punish them and their members will punish them if they give the President a win on anything.

HARF: Chris, Marie Harf here, good morning.

BEDFORD: Good morning.

HARF: I want to ask you a question. Play this out a little bit. Nancy Pelosi takes over speaker, and just a few days, the House will pass likely a clean funding bill with no border wall funding wall in it, the Senate may pass something similar they did earlier, this month, by unanimous consent, if something like that were to pass out of Congress and go to President Trump's desk with no border wall funding in it, will he and should he veto it?

BEDFORD: I suspect that he would veto it because this is a -- this is a campaign promise of his. He'd look like, maybe if they had done these two weeks ago, he might have let something like that by, but the pressure has built, he's becoming -- he's come pretty stubborn on this matter.

And he's really seen a lot of his base start to let him know and tell him, hey, President, we voted for you, in order to get this border wall passed, you had two years to do it, nothing happened. Now, it's down to the last minute, and if you fold again to the Democrats, that's not going to empower them.

Of course, it's possible that he tries to attach it to an infrastructure bill, but again, I don't see any incentive for Nancy Pelosi House of Representatives to give him a win on anything like this.

LAYFIELD: Hey Chris, when you talk about the overall economic impact, I agree with you, history show that government shutdown doesn't have an overall economic impact long term because you get money later, it certainly does and do much (INAUDIBLE) 800,000 people who aren't getting checks at Christmas because of these childish politicians can't get along and worse in D.C.

I think it's embarrassing and disgusting on all of them, both parties. But, when you look at what's going on this past week, with this government shutdown, we're in a stalemate right here. Both sides think they have a winning hand.

Look at what happened with the first Secretary of Defense that resigned, and General Mattis, it seems to lend itself that this White House is either at worst in chaos or at best unpredictable. This is what you think is hurting the image of the White House as much, and also the markets?

BEDFORD: The good news for the government employees who were out of a paycheck, is if the government figures this out by January 10th, then they're never going to even miss a paycheck. They'll be OK because they don't have a scheduled pay period until January 11th. Although, there's a sense of uncertainty you don't want.

But this has been a really, really bad two weeks for the White House, I was with a number of Conservatives over Christmas and over the break, talking about this, and I had never heard some of these Trump supporters be so down on the President, whether it's over Secretary Mattis, which was a step too far for a lot of the people who support the President, or whether it's over this final, final battle after two years of Republican control for the wall.

But a number of Conservatives and people on the hard right told me, that they said that if the President had folded on this issue, then they would - - he would've lost their support entirely. So, I think the President has gotten that message.

But this is a function of some of the dysfunction in the White House, where the way President Trump has traditionally run his businesses, as but a very small, very lean team of people who are close to him, and that doesn't work as well with the sprawling federal government, you need to have as many people on there, as possible, working for you at the same time, and empty jobs are not getting filled.

TIMPF: Hi, it's Katherine, I just have a question, in terms of how this all ends, what do you think would be better, politically, for the President if he ends the shutdown or do you think Conservatives would see it as him folding, if he doesn't get border wall funding?

BEDFORD: I think Conservatives will see it as him folding, absolutely. The best possible outcome for the President would be some kind of compromise where Democrats say they'll give a little bit more for a wall, but maybe it wouldn't be a wall, maybe it'll be steel slots, or something. He'll claim a victory there, and then, he won't at least -- no one would go home empty handed.

However, if the Democrats also have a possibility to appear to be adults in the room, to give him some kind of compromise like that, and say look, we are the House of Representatives, opened up government, but I also think that right now, both sides don't have that much to lose.

They're two years out from an election, I know this is really cynical, but they don't have that much to lose because voters will forget about some of the squabbling and what they will remember, is if Democrats voted for the wall, or if Republicans did not vote for the wall.

SIMONETTI: Yes. And meanwhile, yesterday they gavelled in and gavelled out, as if this is no big deal, and they're all looking ahead to 2020, even though we're not even in 2019 yet, that's how politics work.

We have a poll from The Des Moines Register, as well as CNN, it was from earlier this month, and it shows that the top Democratic contenders for 2020, among Iowa voters, are Former Vice President Joe Biden, he's leading, followed by Senator Bernie Sanders and Congressman Beto O'Rourke.

Now, this is coming as new reports say Michael Bloomberg, Chris, could be willing to spend upwards of $100 million of his own money, in a campaign for the White House, do you think Bloomberg could get in here?

BEDFORD: I don't think this is the time for Bloomberg. I remember his ads he just ran a few weeks ago, where he was saying, I used to be Republican, and now, I'm a Democrat. That's not the kind of bipartisan, I'm willing to switch on principles, kind of thing, at the last minute.

Vote or movement that's getting voters going on right now, the voters are very much divided. Democrats are not interested in working with Republicans and vice versa, and no one's really looking for a moderate person. You see, for the John Kasichs, or the Michael Bloombergs, there's not a huge rising chorus to get those people to run nationally.

Mitt Romney, he has to go to be a senator for Utah, he's not -- this is not his time to run for President, same thing with someone like Paul Ryan. So, I think that Bloomberg stands less of a chance.

And some of the problems for Democrats right now, with their base having put so much emphasis on different identity politics, are those leaders. Those leading three are all white men, except for maybe, Beto, who's not white, I guess, when he runs against a Cuban, but they're generally white men, and that is not something the Democrats are looking for and that's going to come up a lot in their primaries.

SIMONETTI: Marie, what do you think the Democratic ticket in 2020 looks like then?

HARF: I think we have no idea. You know, that poll is basically a name recognition poll, at this point, and if you look at polls from the same time, in the 2016 cycle, in the 2008 cycle, where Hillary Clinton -- no, Barack Obama was in poll, and anywhere close to that, in 2006, right?

At this point, in the 2008 cycle, there's going to be 20, 25 people in primary, and I actually think it will -- the process will work out. People that can survive on the national stage will do better, and people who can't, won't.

SIMONETTI: But these big names --

HARF: We have no idea.

SIMONETTI: -- bring in the money.

HARF: They do.

SIMONETTI: I was like, how can Hillary Clinton run again? But, she can fundraise.

HARF: Yes, but she's not -- well, I hope she doesn't run again, I should say that. But you know, fundraising has also changed, we see Beto who raised so much from small dollar donors online. Fundraising is very different today than it was even 10 years ago, in terms of getting those big donors, grassroots donors matter now, a lot more.

LAYFIELD: Where does the Democratic Party go from here? You know, 2009, the Republican Party was in disarray, much like the Democratic Party is right now, the tea party rose. For a while, it influenced elections and it kind of --

HARF: Yes.

LAYFIELD: Right now, the Socialist Party is rising for the same reasons because they are mad at the political leadership. Where does that go from here?

HARF: There's going to be fight in the Democratic Party in 2020, because there are some high-profile progressives like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who did win, but the reason Democrats won the -- won the majority in the House, is because of moderates who won in the Midwest, in the plain states, in the south.

There's going to be a fight over who can win, and the most important thing will be, who can beat Donald Trump.

SIMONETTI: It's going to be a very interesting year.

HARF: Yes.

SIMONETTI: Christopher Bedford, thank you for joining us.

BEDFORD: Thank you.

SIMONETTI: And for all of that. You gave us a lot to talk about here onset.

All right, coming up, retail wreck, J.C. Penney shares falling below a buck, making it a penny stock, $0.97 for the first time, in its very long history. This, as Sears hits the deadline today, to find a buyer for its assets or disappear forever.

Plus, no New Year's Eve is complete without a glass of bubbly, we've got a look at some of the top wine picks to ring in 2019.

SIMONETTI: Mysterious blue light, filling the New York City's skyline last night. Kristina Partsinevelos, what was this light all about?

PARTSINEVELOS: Oh, that sky was sparking rapid speculation on social media, some suggested it could be a strange weather phenomenon, some even say the aliens -- yes, it's true, but turns out it was a blown transformer in Queens that shined brightly. The small explosion caused some scattered power outages in the city including at La Guardia International Airport; the outage there resulted in multiple flight delays. Thankfully, though, no one was hurt but we love the speculation online.

Last year's special election in Alabama reportedly drawing the attention of the state's Attorney General Steve Marshall telling Washington Post a disinformation campaign targeting GOP Senate Candidate Roy Moore may have violated state campaign laws and affected the outcome of the race. Moore was defeated by Democrat Doug Jones. Marshall says his office is collecting information about the Russian-styled disinformation campaign called "Project Birmingham." Meanwhile, LinkedIn Founder, Reid Hoffman, is apologizing for giving money to the group allegedly behind the campaign. Hoffman says, he was unaware of its tactics.

And bids to acquire Sears are due and U.S. bankers see court today at 4:00 p.m. But Sears Chairman Eddie Lampert, the only buyer who has expressed interest in keeping Sears in business is reportedly struggling to come up with financing to make good on its $4.6 billion offer to buy the company.

And since we're speaking of struggling retailers, J.C. Penny just became a penny stock. Shares of the company fell as low as $0.32 before closing down 7.5 percent at $0.97. It's the first time they've ever closed before a dollar since J.C. Penny went public in late 1970s. Shares of the company down nearly 70 percent this year. I heard one of you whistle. Has anybody went to J.C. Penny just within the last year or so?

SIMONETTI: Well, that's the problem. I mean, retail is strong right now but not for everybody. I don't know. Anyone go to J.C. Penny in the last year?

TIMPF: No, most certainly not.

SIMONETTI: Anyone see the blue light last night?

TIMPF: I was asleep. I was asleep at 8:30.

SIMONETTI: If you saw it at home, tweet us. Apparently, had to be in Queens. Coming up, it's almost time to ring in 2019 and nothing says celebration like a bottle of bubbly. We've got wide array of wines you can toast to when the ball drops.

SIMONETTI: Perfect song. The countdown to 2019 is on. Nothing says a celebration like a glass of bubbly, but that's not the only drink you can choose to ring in the New Year with. Joining me now is Wheeling Forward Co-Founder and University Club Head, Sommelier Yannick Benjamin. Thanks for coming on.

YANNICK BENJAMIN, FOUNDER, WHEELING FORWARD: Well, thanks for having me.

SIMONETTI: You brought your goods.

BENJAMIN: Yes.

SIMONETTI: This is an alternative to champagne, a sparkling wine.

BENJAMIN: Right. So, this is from the (INAUDIBLE). It's from Maurice Bonime, and so it's an alternative to champagne, it's from -- this region is called the garden of France. So, a beautiful little place, it's Chenin blanc. You get it in retail store about $12.00, so significantly less than champagne. So, if you want to save some money and then invest in other wines, you can also do that too.

SIMONETTI: Two questions: do you get the same champagne hangover?

BENJAMIN: Little bit less because less chemicals or whatever. But, you know, it's a natural wine, wonderful, beautiful -- yes, you'll be fine. And the most important thing, it'll put big smile on the face.

SIMONETTI: And the second question was: do you actually speak French or have you just perfected --

BENJAMIN: My parents are French, actually.

SIMONETTI: OK. So -- all right, you do. And what is this over hear?

BENJAMIN: So, this one over here, this is fun. This is from the famous region of Bordeaux, which is commonly known for red wines, but they do so much more than that. They some really great sparkling wines out there, some dry whites, but this is a sweet wine. And we often think sweet wines with dessert, but you can actually do as an (INAUDIBLE), which cheeses just to start it off. My mom is from Bordeaux. So, commonly, we would have sweet wine to start off the meal or even to just celebrate, to just kind of do a little toast for the new year.

SIMONETTI: Right, and you brought two reds.

BENJAMIN: Yes, for sure. Yes, this is a dry red over hear. This is a (INAUDIBLE). 100 percent (INAUDIBLE). I like this; give it a nice little chill so people like red wines, just flavorful, beautiful red fruit aromas to it -- little cranberry notes to it. So, just a perfect little red wine for --

SIMONETTI: Delicious -- I'm a red wine kind of gal. And then, I'm very excited to talk to you about, about this one that I see is open.

BENJAMIN: Yes, I popped it open. So, I wanted you to -- I decanted it for you, I put it back in the bottle so you can taste later on. But this is my private label for my nonprofit called (INAUDIBLE) which is an homage to my parents, it's called the Dreamer. 100 percent of the proceeds goes to (INAUDIBLE), which is a nonprofit to help other people with physical disabilities -- we help them find housing, education, all that good stuff.

SIMONETTI: How much have you raised thus far?

BENJAMIN: I don't know the number of I how much money I raised, but I can tell you we have two wellness and physical fitness centers, so it's been very successful.

SIMONETTI: Well, help you raised money right now. How much is this bottle?

BENJAMIN: This one, you can find for $49.99. But again, a 100 --

SIMONETTI: He says, you're joking -- it's for a good cause.

BENJAMIN: It's for a good cause, but you can go on our Web site, (INAUDIBLE) and you can purchase it. Or there's a great wine store down in (INAUDIBLE) called (INAUDIBLE).

SIMONETTI: Well, you blended it yourself.

BENJAMIN: Yes, I did.

SIMONETTI: So, what goes into -- what are the trends in wine right now?

BENJAMIN: The trends in wines, yes, I think people want, you know, hands off, minimal, organic and honest wines. Wines that when you're tasting, it really -- you know, it takes you back to that place: beautiful aromas, beautiful taste and food friendly as well.

SIMONETTI: OK. Well, I'm going to smell it for the aroma. I love when you --

(LAUGHTER)

SIMONETTI: People who really know wine can pick -- I smell cinnamon bun in this one.

BENJAMIN: There's a little (INAUDIBLE) on it, so there's some vanilla notes --

(CROSSTALK)

SIMONETTI: OK, I'm might pick up vanilla now that you say it. Maybe I'll smell it more if I pick up the glass. Sorry.

(LAUGHTER)

SIMONETTI: It's very strong. This is robust red.

BENJAMIN: Yes, it's pinot noir but just, you know, silky, smooth and all that kind of stuff, yes.

SIMONETTI: All right, and how much the sales typically go up at the end of the year because people are celebrating the holidays.

BENJAMIN: Oh my gosh, it's crazy; there's no end to it. You know, but January, they stop. For sure.

SIMONETTI: Yes, everyone is too hangover and poor. And poor in January.

BENJAMIN: And poor, exactly.

SIMONETTI: Maybe, you should continue to buy wine and champagne to drink away your paycheck sorrows.

BENJAMIN: That's right. That's right. Wine is a commodity.

SIMONETTI: Yannick Benjamin, thank you so much.

BENJAMIN: Thank you so much for having me.

SIMONETTI: Thank you for everything that you do. All right, still ahead, everybody, Instagram's mea cupla; the social media service apologizing for a new update that users including myself absolutely hated yesterday, did you see it? We're going to tell you next about that on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

SIMONETTI: Good morning. I'm Lauren Simonetti, in for Maria Bartiromo today. It is Friday, December 28th. Here are your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern Time. The bulls came out for a run this morning. They're still running; it could change any second now, but Dow is up 121 points, S&P up 13, NASDAQ tacking on 21 after a roller coaster day yesterday and quite frankly, for the fourth quarter. The Dow swinging more than 150 points during yesterday's session. It did finish higher by more than one percent. The S&P 500 picking up just about one percent and the NASDAQ tacking on just over a third of a percent. Meanwhile, in Europe, green across the screen. They're all up 1.6 percent. Asian markets overnight mostly higher. The Nikkei in Japan down a third of one percent and it is - -

Wall Street powered back today in a huge advance to end the first wild week of the year 2000 on a strong note. The Nasdaq soared more than four percent and the Dow surged to a record. Plus, American workers hit the job jackpot last month and last year, according to the latest numbers from the government. The economy created more jobs than expected in December, with unemployment at 4.1 percent, the lowest rate since January 1970. And, American companies may dominate the wired world, but in wireless technology America is a latecomer. The world leader is Nokia, out of Finland.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight, a wild week on Wall Street ends with a powerful rally. The Dow shoots to a record. And the Nasdaq scores its biggest one-day point gain ever.

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: Left out of the comeback, America's most widely held stock, Lucent plunges in the most-active trading ever on the big board.

BAY: The boom is alive on Wall Street -- and Main Street. More than 10,000 jobs a day created last month, and unemployment holds at a three-decade low.

VARNEY: And we'll look at the wireless world of Nokia, in "The Bottom Line," the cell phone king that emerged from Finland not Japan.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

K.P. WILSKA, PRESIDENT, NOKIA AMERICAS: Nokia has been looked like being a Japanese company, because the name looks like Japanese name, even though I don't look too much Japanese.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VARNEY: A powerhouse finish to a tumultuous week on Wall Street.

BAY: A week that brought the Nasdaq to the brink of a correction. Wall Street powered back today in a huge advance to end the first wild week of the year 2000 on a strong note. The Nasdaq soared more than four percent and the Dow surged to a record. The rebound is even more impressive considering that investors had reason to fear going into today's trading,

Rhonda Schaffler has more in today's "Street Sweep."

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

RHONDA SCHAFFLER, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): At the opening bell on Wall Street, traders were braced for another wild ride. Technology investors hear the fallout of Lucent Technologies first ever profit warnings and a report showing job growth is even more vigorous than expected, raised expectations of an interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. But investors showed no fear, buying blue chips with abandon and tech stock with zeal. The Dow moved through a start-stop session to claim a 269-point advance, up 2.4 percent to end with a new record, 11,522. On the Nasdaq, the composite recovered from a week of abuse to reclaim more than 155 points, finishing at 3,882, a single session rise of 4.2 percent. Many analysts had expected disappointment with Lucent's performance to drain more power from a frazzled tech sector.

CHARLES BETZ, CORNERSTONE CAPITAL MGT.: Lucent's announcement last night reflected, I think, something that is company specific and one or two quarter specific. They claimed that the last half of their year will make up for the short fall in the first two quarters of their year. So I don't think techs going to be -- show us too many surprises on the earnings front.

AT&T spun off Lucent in 1996. Up until yesterday, the stock was trading at 10 times its IPO price.

But that kind of performance can also inspire fierce loyalty, as Greg Clarkin reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GREG CLARKIN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Richard Zito and Doug Flynn run a financial planning firm on New York's Long Island, and there is one stock everyone wanted to talk about today, Lucent.

RICHARD ZITO, FLYNN ZITO CAPITAL MNGMT.: It was unprecedented from the standpoint that in such a short period of time this morning we had so many calls.

CLARKIN: Lucent is the most widely-held stock in the country, more than three billion shares outstanding. The telecommunications equipment maker said profits will not be what Wall Street expected. Its shares dived in after-hours trading, wiping out almost $51 billion, or about one-quarter of its market capital.

Bank of AmericaCapital Management lost about $250 million on its $1 billion investment in Lucent in after-hours trading, but it hung on to its shares, and even had a glimmer of good news as Lucent shares picked up $1 in New York trading.

JOHN ZIMMERMAN, BANC OF AMERICA CAPITAL MGMT.: It was a very large drop, and it's obviously an unpleasant experience as a shareholder, but our feeling is that Lucent remains well positioned, and we're very heartened to see the $1 or so increase in the share price over the course of business today. It seems like a lot of people got to the point where they were comfortable with the valuation.

CLARKIN: And many smaller investors sensed an opportunity in the battered stock.

ZITO: I was very surprised to see that the calls were people were looking to buy as opposed to sell. I think they feel -- like most clients, like most people -- that it is such a strong company that it's just a small bump in the road.

CLARKIN (on camera): And despite the fact that many analysts expect Lucent's problems to linger, many investors say they expect Lucent's shares to quietly creep back to pre-profit warning levels.

Greg Clarkin, CNN financial news, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: But it's not all good news. The details when MONEYLINE returns.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: In tonight's "MONEYLINE Movers," the German software maker SAP stormed up 13 5/8 after reporting that its fourth-quarter profits had nearly doubled. That gain helped propel the German Dax to its biggest gain in a single session.

Tiffany was up nearly 5 1/2 after PaineWebber upgraded the stock to attractive. The jewelry retailer sold off yesterday, despite reporting strong holiday sales.

BAY: In other corporate news, phone carrier McLeodUSA says it will buy Splitrock services, which runs a nationwide high-speed data network. The price tag: close to $2 billion in stock.

Wal-Mart also wants to expand its presence in cyberspace. The country's biggest retailer will form a separate company to enhance its walmart.com site. Wal-Mart will team up with venture capital firm Accel partners, and said it plans to pursue a public offering in the future. Shares of Wal-Mart up more than 4 3/4.

VARNEY: In tonight's sector focus, a stellar day for Internet stocks as investors drove that recently-depressed sector sharply higher, the Goldman Sachs Internet index up nearly 7 percent. B-to-B Internet companies also strong. Ariba, for example, up nearly 19 1/2. Broadvision up more than 19 -- and change, I should say -- though still off 13 percent on the week. Beat that.

BAY: Make all of that volatility, nicely said.

Coming up next: Inside the world's wireless wonder.

VARNEY: Nokia, the cell-phone king, sprung out of Helsinki, not Tokyo.

"The Bottom Line" is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Now, "The Bottom Line," our regular Friday feature inside one company on the move. Tonight, Nokia, the Finnish company that seemed to emerge from obscurity. It's out to create a world without wires.

Peter Viles reports.

VILES (voice-over): American companies may dominate the wired world, but in wireless technology, America is a latecomer, and the world leader is Finland. What Wall Street is to money, what is Hollywood to movies, Finland is to the cellular phone. Six out of 10 Fins carry one, a penetration rate double that of the United States. When stock analysts want to see the future of wireless applications, they go to Helsinki, because the world's leading wireless phone maker is Finland's Nokia, a slimmed-down conglomerate that has outmaneuvered, outhustled and outinnovated competitors Motorola and Ericsson.

ROB GENSLER, T. ROWE PRICE: If you really want to get to the core of Nokia and what makes them great is the pace of innovation. And as long as they keep the pace of innovation up, they will have very great growth and phenomenal margins.

VILES: That innovation included the realization that many customers want a phone that's also the fashion statement, fun, stylish and easy to use.

GENSLER: They have a keen eye for design. They understood far before anybody else that what made handsets powerful was the fact that people were using them and enjoyed using them and design mattered.

VILES: Nokia's growth has been stunning. In 1997, it sold 21 million phones, 20 percent of the global market, 41 million the next year and 72 million last year, good for 30 percent of the wireless market, which is why Nokia's stock has also exploded, up 877 percent over the last two years -- impressive for a company that some consumers still assume is just another Japanese electronics brand.

WILSKA: Because the name looks like Japanese name, even though I don't look too much Japanese.

VILES: Wall Street sees the company's Finnish base as an advantage. It gives Nokia daily access to a test market of five million, a market where Nokia phones are capable of transmitting short text messages, downloading weather reports from the Internet, even talking to other machines and paying for Cokes.

WILSKA: We can foresee that three years, five years from now, people are paying their bills by using their phones. They can go to grocery store and instead of swiping their debit or credit card, they can point their phone at the cash register and pay their bill by using their phone.

VILES: The great opportunity for Nokia is also the great threat. What happens as more and more Internet access is wireless? If everyone from Microsoft to Panasonic wants to build a new pocket computer, will Nokia's advantage last?

MARK MCKECHNIE, BANK OF AMERICA SECURITIES: I think it's going to be interesting to watch the new entrants into this base, such as the Palm, such as HandSpring, who's got the visor product. And so Nokia will have to maintain their leadership, will have to innovate quicker than they to stay ahead of it. But net net, we think they've got the management strength, the history, and the relationship with carriers and the brand name to maintain that leadership.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VILES: Now with or without all those Internet applications, the market for wireless phone service voice service is exploding. It grew 50 percent last year. Four hundred fifty million people globally now have wireless phones, and Nokia predicts it will grow to a billion users, a billion cell phones by the year 2002 -- Stuart.

VARNEY: I've got to ask, though. How do they stay on top over a very long period of time in a very fast-moving industry?

VILES: One of the keys in this business is coming out with a new product even if it might hurt the existing product you have on the market. Intel is also known for this. Analysts refer to this as eating your own young. It's coming to market with a product, even if it hurts what you've got out there.

VARNEY: Get it on the market, get it out there fast.

VILES: Because the consumers are looking for it.

VARNEY: Yes.

BAY: That billion users, where are the users likely to come from?

VILES: All over the world. And the United States is lagging in some areas. Asia and Europe have been the strongest areas where the penetration is the greatest.

Peter Viles, thank you.

VARNEY: Yes.

Up next, "Ahead of the Curve," some of what you need to know tonight before those markets open again next week.

BAY: You are watching MONEYLINE.

On the economic front, we have two important inflation figures coming out, the producer price index and the consumer price index, both for December.

Also due out, figures on retail sales, wholesale trade and the latest numbers on the nation's manufacturing sector, too. In terms of earnings, a few Dow components are expected to report. They include Alcoa, International Paper and Intel -- remember, Intel is now a Dow stock.

Also due out, fourth-quarter results from Yahoo!

VARNEY: And I'm Stuart Varney.

Thanks for joining us. Enjoy that weekend.

urn:contentItem:5RWW-Y511-F021-64MT-00000-00'Wild West' era for technology firms like Facebook and Google is over, minister declares2018-03-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:15ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY INTELLIGENCEVersion:1'Wild West' era for technology firms like Facebook and Google is over, minister declaresBy Harry de Quetteville

The 'Wild West' era for technology firms like Facebook and Google is over, the Cabinet minister responsible for overseeing them declares today.

Silicon Valley giants face much greater regulation to control their use of people's data and ensure they cannot avoid being properly taxed, Matt Hancock warns.

The Secretary of State for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport's comments were made in an interview for Technology Intelligence, a new initiative from the Telegraph dedicated to covering the increasingly important world of technology. 

In t he first of a five part series examining Britain's burgeoning technology industry, Mr Hancock says that the world's biggest companies must accept increasing regulation and taxation by national governments.

The Government will put "rules in place so that tech can be harnessed for the good of the people" adding that "the Wild West for tech companies is over", he says.

"Freedom operates within a framework," he says. "The liberal values of cherishing freedom whilst protecting the freedom of others is the new approach we're taking and the argument we're making in the UK is getting global resonance."

Tech Intelligence story 1 puff

Mr Hancock's intervention comes as Facebook faces increasing scrutiny over how it uses people's data.

MPs yesterday demanded founder Mark Zuckerberg explains how the social media giant allowed a British firm to harvest the details of 50million users in 2014.

Cambridge Analytica has been accused of improperly using the data while working as political analysts for Donald Trump's 2016 presidential team and the successful Brexit campaign. The firm has described the accusations - made by a whistleblower - as 'pure fantasy'.

Yesterday Damian Collins, chairman of the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee, said Mr Zuckerberg should "stop hiding behind his Facebook page" and answer questions about the incident.

Mr Collins said his committee had "repeatedly asked" Facebook about how companies acquire and hold on to user data from the site, and whether information had been taken from people without their consent.

Mr Hancock says that part of the problem is that governments have not been able to keep pace with rapid technological change.

He says that the "break things fast, then fix them" entrepreneurial attitude common in Silicon Valley needs to evolve as very young companies have quickly become the biggest on the planet, holding huge amounts of data on billions of people and developing powerful new technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI). 

"The tech industry grew up with a libertarian attitude that the government should just get out of the way because connecting people would improve lives," he says.

"And for the vast majority of people that is true. But it isn't true for everybody. 

"The rules that society has - whether norms of behaviour or formal legislative and regulatory rules - have not kept up with technology.

"For emerging technologies like AI (artificial intelligence), putting in place the framework in which the technology operates is incredibly important.

"We as a society need to ensure that the framework in which tech operates is strong and robust. The trick is to pull off is to support the innovation and the amazing freedoms that this technology allows while ensuring that it works for the good of mankind," he says. 

Facebook by numbers

Britain's determination to strike a balance between regulation and innovation would help this country become a global leader in technology, he adds.

Mr Hancock describes himself as a "the most pro-tech person you could imagine" and "a massive optimist for the power of technology".

But he describes how, on issues such as online pornography, Britain has led the way on rethinking and strengthening regulation. 

Mr Hancock says: "In the old world children couldn't get hold of porn very easily - it was physically on the top shelf. In the new [digital] world it was absurdly easy. 

"We've brought in legislation in the UK so that porn sites need to have age verification and most of the porn sites are changing their rules globally because of the UK."

Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google are among the companies which have been accused of unfairly minimising tax bills while growing increasingly influential in the lives of billions.

The Treasury is already examining the idea of taxing tech companies' revenues rather than their profits, in a move designed to prevent global corporations shifting money around the world to lower their tax bills. 

Mr Hancock says it was "very important that big tech companies play fair and pay an appropriate amount of tax".

urn:contentItem:5RSW-BJ71-JCJY-G50P-00000-00Will 2018 be the year of the neo-luddite?;The downsides of technology's inexorable march are ?now becoming clear - and automation will only increase the anxiety. We should expect the ?growing interest in off-grid lifestyles to be accompanied by ?direct action and even anti-tech riots2018-03-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:15ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYVersion:1Will 2018 be the year of the neo-luddite?The downsides of technology's inexorable march are ?now becoming clear - and automation will only increase the anxiety. We should expect the ?growing interest in off-grid lifestyles to be accompanied by ?direct action and even anti-tech riotsJamie Bartlett

One of the great paradoxes of digital life - understood and exploited by the tech giants - is that we never do what we say. Poll after poll in the past few years has found that people are worried about online privacy and do not trust big tech firms with their data. But they carry on clicking and sharing and posting, preferring speed and convenience above all else. Last year was Silicon Valley's annus horribilis: a year of bots, Russian meddling, sexism, monopolistic practice and tax-minimising. But I think 2018 might be worse still: the year of the neo-luddite, when anti-tech words turn into deeds.

The caricature of machine-wrecking mobs doesn't capture our new approach to tech. A better phrase is what the writer Blake Snow has called "reformed luddism" : a society that views tech with a sceptical eye, noting the benefits while recognising that it causes problems, too. And more importantly, thinks that something can be done about it.

One expression of reformed luddism is already causing a headache for the tech titans. Facebook and Google are essentially huge advertising firms. Ad-blocking software is their kryptonite. Yet millions of people downloaded these plug-ins to stop ads chasing them across the web last year, and their use has been growing (on desktops at least) close to 20% each year, indiscriminately hitting smaller publishers, too.

More significantly, the whole of society seems to have woken up to the fact there is a psychological cost to constant checking, swiping and staring. A growing number of my friends now have "no phone" times, don't instantly sign into the cafe wifi, or have weekends away without their computers. This behaviour is no longer confined to intellectuals and academics, part of some clever critique of modernity. Every single parent I know frets about "screen time", and most are engaged in a struggle with a toddler over how much iPad is allowed. The alternative is "slow living" or "slow tech". "Want to become a slow-tech family?" writes Janell Burley Hoffmann, one of its proponents. "Wait! Just wait - in line, at the doctor's, for the bus, at the school pickup - just sit and wait." Turning what used to be ordinary behaviour into a "movement" is a very modern way to go about it. But it's probably necessary.

I would add to this the ever-growing craze for yoga, meditation, reiki and all those other things that promise inner peace and meaning - except for the fact all the techies do it, too. Maybe that's why they do it. Either way, there is a palpable demand for anything that involves less tech, a fetish for back-to-basics. Innocent Drinks have held two "Unplugged Festivals", offering the chance of "switching off for the weekend... No wifi, no 3G, no traditional electricity". Others take off-grid living much further. There has been an uptick in "back to the land" movements: communes and self-sustaining communities that prefer the low-tech life. According to the Intentional Community Directory, which measures the spread of alternative lifestyles, 300 eco-villages were founded in the first 10 months of 2016, the most since the 1970s. I spent some time in 2016 living in an off-grid community where no one seemed to suffer mobile phone separation anxiety. No one was frantically checking if their last tweet went viral and we all felt better for it.

Even insiders are starting to wonder what monsters they've unleashed. Former Google "design ethicist" Tristan Harris recently founded the nonprofit organisation Time Well Spent in order to push back against what he calls a "digital attention crisis" of our hijacked minds. Most of the tech conferences I'm invited to these days include this sort of introspection: is it all going too far? Are we really the good guys?

That tech firms are responding is proof they see this is a serious threat: many more are building in extra parental controls, and Facebook admitted last year that too much time on their site was bad for your health, and promised to do something. Apple investors recently wrote to the company, suggesting the company do more to "ensure that young consumers are using your products in an optimal manner" - a bleak word combination to describe phone-addled children, but still.

It's worth reflecting what a radical change all this is. That economic growth isn't everything, that tech means harm as well as good - this is not the escape velocity, you-can't-stop-progress thinking that has colonised our minds in the past decade. Serious writers now say things that would have been unthinkable until last year: even the FT calls for more regulation and the Economist asks if social media is bad for democracy.

This reformed luddism does not however mean the end of good, old-fashioned machine-smashing. The original luddites did not dislike machines per se, rather what they were doing to their livelihoods and way of life. It's hard not to see the anti-Uber protests in a similar light. Over the past couple of years, there have been something approaching anti-Uber riots in Paris ; in Hyderabad, India, drivers took to the streets to vent their rage against unmet promises of lucrative salaries; angry taxi drivers blocked roads last year across Croatia, Hungary and Poland. In Colombia, there were clashes with police, while two Uber vehicles were torched in Johannesburg and 30 metered taxi drivers arrested.

Imagine what might happen when driverless cars turn up. The chancellor has recently bet on them, promising investment and encouraging real road testing; he wants autonomous vehicles on our streets by 2021. The industry will create lots of new and very well-paid jobs, especially in robotics, machine learning and engineering. For people with the right qualifications, that's great. And for the existing lorry and taxi drivers? There will still be some jobs, since even Google tech won't be able to handle Swindon's magic roundabout for a while. But we will need far fewer of them. A handful might retrain, and claw their way up to the winner's table. I am told repeatedly in the tech startup bubble that unemployed truckers in their 50s should retrain as web developers and machine-learning specialists, which is a convenient self-delusion. Far more likely is that, as the tech-savvy do better than ever, many truckers or taxi drivers without the necessary skills will drift off to more precarious, piecemeal, low-paid work.

Does anyone seriously think that drivers will passively let this happen, consoled that their great-grandchildren may be richer and less likely to die in a car crash? And what about when Donald Trump's promised jobs don't rematerialise, because of automation rather than offshoring and immigration? Given the endless articles outlining how "robots are coming for your jobs", it would be extremely odd if people didn't blame the robots, and take it out on them, too.

Once people start believing that machines are a force of oppression rather than liberation, there will be no stopping it. Between 1978 and 1995, the Unabomber, Ted Kaczynski, sent 16 bombs to targets including universities and airlines, killing three people and injuring 23. Kaczynski, a Harvard maths prodigy who began to live off-grid in his 20s, was motivated by a belief that technological change was destroying human civilisation, ushering in a period of dehumanised tyranny and control. Once you get past Kaczynski's casual racism and calls for violent revolution, his writings on digital technology now seem uncomfortably prescient. He predicted super-intelligent machines dictating society, the psychological ill-effects of tech-reliance and the prospect of obscene inequality as an elite of techno-savvies run the world.

The American philosopher John Zerzan is considered the intellectual heavyweight for the anarcho-primitivist movement, whose adherents believe that technology enslaves us. They aren't violent, but boy do they do hate tech. During the Unabomber's trial, Zerzan became a confidant to Kaczynski, offering support for his ideas while condemning his actions. Zerzan is finding himself invited to speak at many more events, and the magazine he edits has seen a boost in sales. "Something's going on," he tells me - by phone, ironically. "The negative of technology is now taken as a given." I ask if he could forsee the emergence of another Unabomber. "I think it's inevitable," he says. "As things get worse, you're not going to stop it any other way," although he adds that he hopes it doesn't involve violence against people.

There are signs that full-blown neo-luddism is already here. In November last year, La Casemate, a tech "fab lab" based in Grenoble, France, was vandalised and burned. The attackers called it "a notoriously harmful institution by its diffusion of digital culture". The previous year, a similar place in Nantes was targeted. Aside from an isolated incident in Mexico in 2011, this is, as far as I can tell, the first case since the Unabomber of an act of violence targeting technology explicitly as technology, rather than just a proxy for some other problem. The French attackers' communique was published by the environmentalist/anarchist journal Earth First! and explained how the internet's promise of liberation for anticapitalists has evaporated amid more surveillance, more control, more capitalism. "Tonight, we burned the Casemate," it concludes. "Tomorrow, it will be something else, and our lives will be too short, in prison or in free air, because everything we hate can burn."

If the recent speculation about jobs and AI is even close to being correct, then fairly soon "luddite" will join far-right and Islamist on the list of government-defined extremisms. Perhaps anti-tech movements will even qualify for the anti-radicalisation Prevent programme.

No one wants machines smashed or letter bombs. The wreckers failed 200 years ago and will fail again now. But a little luddism in our lives won't hurt. The realisation that technological change isn't always beneficial nor inevitable is long overdue, and that doesn't mean jettisoning all the joys associated with modern technology. You're not a fogey for thinking there are times where being disconnected is good for you. You're just not a machine.
